The musician looked up from his plate, setting his fork down. "Yeah, you heard right," Randy confessed. 

Winston waited a beat, then asked, "Got any other vices we should know about?"

Randy chuckled grimly. "Well, I have a knack for getting my money into the wrong hands at the poker table."

Winston nodded, making a note of it. Before moving onto the next subject, he specified, "Got news yesterday - a revolver was found, identical to the one you were seen with at a music concert. It turned out to be the murder weapon." 

Randy paused and shrugged. "Got it for protection. You never know who you might run into on the road. I only ever use it for shooting at the range."

Whilst Randy was talking, Winston noticed the deep scars on Randy's fingers in the dim neon light. They were all identical in their presence, all etched with the same depth and characteristics. Being a man of detail, Winston asked Randy about them.

"Those?" Randy looked at his hands with a sad laughter. "Each scar on my hand came from a different guitar string breaking at a concert, all of them had a unique tale to tell," he said. Then he added, "usual guitar injuries are just mere blisters, not deep scars like these. But what can I say? Bad luck follows me around".

Winston, though intrigued, refrained from reading anything into it. He then moved the conversation toward Randy's past interactions with the victim, the international hotel mogul, Jimmy.

“So you knew Jimmy. The guy owned hotels from Tokyo to New York,” Winston stated.

"Jimmy, he loved his opulence. Always surrounded by luxury," Randy shrugged. "Not that I ever got a slice of it, of course. I played in a few of his hotels... never got the invite to the penthouse." 

Winston thanked Randy for his time and left the diner. There were more aspects of this case to sniff out. All in a day’s work.

Detective Winston sat across from Isla at the local coffee shop, the smell of burnt coffee wafting around them. 

Isla played less of a nervous suspect and leaned more into her usual friendly demeanor. Although they usually ran into each other at the gym, today's meetup was not about catching up on fitness routines. Just the other day, she had confessed to a friend on the treadmill beside her that she couldn't bear the blackmail from Jimmy anymore.

"Jimmy...he...he was blackmailing me, Detective Winston," Isla confessed, bleakly stirring her coffee. Her hopelessness was clear, something she had mentioned to her friends recently regarding the relentless blackmail. 

Winston didn't show his surprise. He just nodded and gestured for her to continue. 

"We used to meet at a motel down the road. Crazy, right? But it was the only place we could talk without being seen. I was even there on the day of the murder," Isla confessed. That fact was uncovered in a police report which witnessed Isla at the motel on the day of Jimmy's murder.

Winston knew this already, having received a report of Isla being spotted with Jimmy at the motel quite a few times in the past. He just grunted, encouraging her to keep speaking. 

"It's not what you think. He...he took some photos...and threatened to expose them." Isla shuddered, her coffee cup rattling in her hand. 

"Did you ever confront him about it?" Winston asked, looking unwaveringly at Isla. 

"Yes, I did! I couldn't stand it any longer, Detective. That day...the day he was killed...I was going to tell him it had to stop," Isla admitted, her voice raw with emotion. 

"And then what happened?" Winston asked, watching Isla's face carefully. 

"I...I don't remember," Isla said, running a hand through her hair. "I was so worked up. I just...I ended up at the shooting range. It helps...calm me down."

Winston groaned internally on hearing this. Isla had been seen at the shooting range more often than not lately, supposedly to "blow off some steam". On one occasion, she had talked extensively about her growing gun collection to another gym buddy, which was a recurring topic she loved to discuss with anyone who'd lend an ear. She was often heard discussing different types of firearms amidst these conversations. 

"Do you remember what time it was when you left the range?" Winston asked. But Isla shook her head, looking gloomy, and didn't say a word. 

Winston sighed and checked his watch. The interview was close to being over, and he needed to gather more facts to help solve the case. But in the back of his mind, he couldn't help but dwell on the circumstances... Hopeless. Desperate. A lineup of damning coincidences. But the one most nagging thought that lingered as he got up to leave was the overpowering scent of burnt coffee: just how much it reminded him of gunpowder.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the dimly lit corners of a rundown motel, Jimmy's life was abruptly silenced by the ominous echo of a revolver, leaving Detective Winston with two enigmatic suspects - Isla, with her elusive charm, and Randy, the taciturn stranger.

Winston flicked through the photos of the seedy motel crime scene, located just out of town. The murder of Jimmy had taken him by surprise; the wealthy hotelier owned multiple hotels worldwide and was known for his love of high-end luxury, a stark contrast to the modest locale where he met his untimely demise.

Slipping the photographs back into their manila envelope, Winston set his sights on his main person of interest, a guitarist named Randy. Not only was he seen at the motel the exact day Jimmy was killed, he was also seen entering Jimmy's room, a fact uncovered from an interrogation of motel guests as there were no CCTV cameras to corroborate their claims. Their room keys weren’t distinctly marked either, allowing anyone to access any room if they possessed a similar key.

Randy, known in circles for his habitual participation in poker games, had gambled away his income putting him in a tough spot financially. The man was drowning in debt, unable to pay off his loans and this murder could potentially be tied to his monetary problems.

Winston stepped into a local dive bar where Randy was performing. His exceptional dexterity, as he played the guitar, was quite noticeable. A guitarist's finger agility and coordination would be beneficial to a shooter.

Having seen Randy perform a few solos, Winston made his move, "Mind if I join you, Randy?" Winston asked, sliding into the bar seat next to the musician. "Of course, officer. What can I play for you?" Randy asked, strumming a slow, bluesy riff.

"Actually, what I need isn't a song," Winston said, leaning in a little closer. "A few folks saw you at Jimmy's room at the motel and you were also spotted with a revolver at a concert last month. Anything you'd like to share?"

Randy strummed his guitar a beat longer before halting, looking away before returning his gaze to Winston. "Yeah, I knew Jimmy." He confirmed. "We've crossed paths a few times."

"You frequent the shooting range around here much?" Winston probed further, sensing a shift in Randy's demeanor. "Yeah, I do. I like to shoot around, helps clear my head."

"And that revolver, the same you flaunted at the concert last month... was that the one you used at the target range?" Further probing, Winston felt Randy's guard starting to falter.

 "That's the one. But what does this have to do with Jimmy? I heard he was killed with a revolver."

"On the nose, Randy." Winston's words were void of emotion. "Ballistics confirmed the revolver used to kill Jimmy was identical to yours."

Seemingly cornered, Randy retorted with a bitter remark; "Every revolver around here looks like that." 

With empathy lacing his voice, Winston closed, "Well if you need any help with those looming loan repayments, I'd be more than happy to point you towards the right resources." 

With that, Winston left Randy pondering at the bar, lost in his thoughts.

Winston was a beer and steak, sawdust and power-tools kind of man. He wasn't familiar with this world of protein shakes, barbells, and sweaty gym enthusiasts. Yet, here he was, investigating a case that led him to a gym, talking to a woman named Isla.

Isla. A lean woman with lightened hair that fell to her shoulders. She looked like the typical sort to blend into this gym environment, but there was something different about her. Not in an obvious sort of way, more like an exception you'd find in an otherwise uniform crowd, hidden at first glance.

She was talking to her friend nearby, her face wrought with concern and frustration. As Winston inched closer, he overheard her whispering, "I can't bear it anymore, Jess...this blackmail from Jimmy...." 

"Hi, sorry for interrupting. I'm Winston, a detective. Just a few questions, if you don't mind?" said Winston, taking out his notepad and pen. He watched as Isla swallowed hard and nodded, adjusting the straps of a gym bag which seemed heavier than it should be.

"Been here long?" Winston started, attempting a casual tone.

"Most of my days may as well start and end here," Isla ironically chuckled, wiping the sweat from her brow. That’s when Winston noticed the book falling out of her gym bag. 'Forensics for Dummies', it read. A few other gym attendees nearby gawked at it, mouths gaping, one of them mentioning, "Isn't that the book she's always rambling about? I swear she keeps discussing trace evidence and bullet trajectories while doing her cardio."

"Interesting read there," Winston gestured towards the book. Isla looked at him hesitantly before nodding, "I'm trying to...get some control over my situation," she admitted, indirectly revealing her desperation to stop the blackmail.

He decided to ask her about Jimmy, watching as her eyes showed a flash of fear, "I heard you and Jimmy were quite close," he continued, keeping his tone casual, non-accusatory.

Isla appeared defensive, "We've met up a few times. At the motel downtown," she added hurriedly as if she wanted to get it out there before Winston asked.

"The evening Jimmy died, by any chance were you at the motel?" Winston asked her. He watched her closely as she looked at him, confirming without uttering a word.

"Anyone to vouch for you?" he continued. She hesitated, "No... No, I was alone," she confessed quietly.

"Motive is often a strong feeling," he said, almost to himself more than to her. "Jimmy was blackmailing you, wasn't he? Threatened to expose some photos?"

His question seemed to visibly shake her, "Yes...those photos...he threatened...," she trailed off, looking even more upset than when Winston first laid his eyes on her. The room filled with the noise of clanking weights and blaring music, but Isla and Winston sat in their own wall of silence.

"Alright," Winston concluded, not pressing her any further. "Take care of yourself, Isla," he said before walking away. He had learned enough for the day. Now, the puzzle of Jimmy's death was waiting to be solved. Even if gym visits were not Winston's preference, he was willing to solve the mystery.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the chilling silence of a hockey rink, Marvin's life was brutally ended with a machete, leaving Detective Winston with two elusive suspects: Justin and Frederick.

Winston sifted through the reports on his desk: the hockey rink homicide, the outlandish murder weapon, the victim known as Marvin who was scheduled to play a hockey game that fateful day. His attention fell onto a single name: Justin.

Leaning back in his chair, Winston found his thoughts weaving around Justin's profession—a piercer; an occupation requiring specific tools like needles and, in Justin's unique case, machetes.

He recalled his past dealings with Justin, particularly how he demonstrated a morose disposition after his proposal got rejected. Winston recalled the desperation in Justin's eyes as he recounted his romantic proposal to Marvin's fiancé. Unfortunately for him, the lady chose Marvin over him.

Justin, who had been frequenting Marvin's hockey games, was there again for the scheduled match. When he arrived, he found Justin waiting amidst the empty seats.

"You watched Marvin's hockey game frequently, yeah?" Winston began, staring up at Justin with a curiosity that was intense. Justin's face distorted with pain as he gave a nod in affirmation, silently communicating his reasons for being there the day of the murder.

Winston shifted on his feet and continued, "You were here that day, weren’t you? To watch Marvin play?"

"I came to watch the game, like always. It was just unfortunate what happened," Justin replied, his voice empty of any emotion.

Winston took a moment before continuing, "I have full CCTV footage of you entering the rink at the time of Marvin's scheduled game, and not leaving until an hour after the murder was supposedly committed." 

Pulling out a photo of a distinct, ornate machete from his coat pocket, he asked: "Recognize this? CCTV also shows you carrying a bag into the rink of such size and shape, which could've carried this. And forensics confirmed that this machete, with your piercing studio's distinct engravings, was the murder weapon."

Justin's eyes widened as truthful recognition flashed in them. Winston's next visit would be Justin's piercing parlor.

Justin's piercing studio was like an alternate world. Display cases filled with shiny replicas of machetes were fixed on the walls; a reminder of his unique craft. An odd weapon for a piercer, but it seems it had become Justin's tool of choice. Upon inquiring the staff, he found that only Justin handled these machetes. Furthermore, no other employee had access to them.

His next stop was to Marvin's fiancé, a delicate woman, embodying sorrow and distraught. 

"Justin approached you about not marrying Marvin, didn’t he?" Winston struck a direct chord, to which she only nodded, tears welling up in her eyes.

Following the tiring day of investigation, Winston drove back to the precinct. Entering the rink at the time Marvin was scheduled to play, Justin's presence at the murder site, his connection with the weapon, his relations with the victim and Marvin's fiancé - all confirmed by CCTV and forensic evidence, he had gathered ample information. Now, it was time to piece it all together.

The biting chill at the crime scene did nothing to alleviate the morbid spectacle in front of Winston. Marvin's body, brutally murdered with a machete and left on the icy, hockey rink made for an astonishing scene. 

Marvin was no saint though. Rumors of his volatile behavior had circulated around town for quite some time.

Having gone through the initial inspection of the crime scene, Winston decided to pay Frederick a visit at his spacious residence next to the cemetery. The presence of Frederick's numerous antique machetes at the crime scene was too much of a coincidence to ignore. The man had far too many in his collection for it to go unnoticed. Frederick, in his role as the curator of the local weapons museum, had unrestricted access to a range of armaments. And curiously, Marvin had been killed with a weapon from Frederick's extensive collection.

Upon reaching the house, Winston noticed Frederick fitting the key into the lock of the cemetery gate, signifying his unrestricted access to the nearby graveyard. 

As he walked up to the front porch, he noticed an ominous array of mourning books displayed on a nearby table. He asked about them and Frederick proudly claimed them to be a part of his vast collection documenting rituals from many different cultures.

Upon greeting Frederick, he was immediately shown inside by Frederick's anxious daughter. She was noticeably shaken up from hearing of Marvin's murder, considering that Marvin had recently publicly threatened her. 

Upon hearing that, Frederick's reaction was expected. He was an incredibly protective father and the news visibly upset him. 

Frederick, seeming desperate to change the topic started talking about his travels, elaborating how he was tasked with visiting and studying the weapons and tombs of ancient cultures.

Sensing Frederick's discomfort, Winston decided to leave the conversation there. He observed his surroundings one final time before thanking them for their hospitality and reminding them to stay safe.

As he strolled back to his car, he noted the machete from Frederick's collection stationed in the museum, something he had been specifically overseeing.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the chilling silence of a hockey rink, Marvin's life was brutally ended with a machete, leaving Detective Winston with two elusive suspects: Justin and Frederick.

Detective Winston made his way through the bustling crowds at the local hockey rink. The place had a distinct, chilling atmosphere today, the murder of Marvin casting a grim shadow over it.

He spotted Justin not too far away, watching the game with a fixed expression. Justin had been noticeably depressed since a particular event - he had once proposed to Marvin's fiancé, expressing his undying love, only to be mercilessly rejected. After this incident, he was never quite the same, living with a constant air of despair and refusal to engage with happiness.

"Justin," Winston called out, making his way over. As soon as Justin heard the detective's approach and caught sight of the man in uniform, his eyes instantly lit up, always eager to gain more information about the crime.

"Detective," Justin greeted, his expression somber, yet subtly eager, "here for the game or here about the recent crime?"

Winston raised a brow. Justin seemed too interested. "Any hockey fan would be here for the game," he replied, "Marvin was going to play, wasn't he?"

Justin's dry eyes took on a spark when the murder was mentioned again. He looked dejected at the mention of Marvin, but nodded, "Yeah, he was. I was here to watch it." He had been with the crowd entering the hockey rink at the time of the murder, ready for the game and totally unprepared for the tragedy that eventually unfolded.

He paused, glancing around the rink, then asked, "Do you know how they got in? The murderer, I mean."

Winston kept his expression unreadable, but he noted Justin's quick change of topic back to the crime. "Through the main entrance," he stated simply, "like anyone else," he added, reaffirming that Justin had entered the same way.

"And the time... when exactly did it happen?" Justin changed the topic right back to the crime again, the flame in his eyes burning brighter at the prospect of new details.

Winston frowned slightly, "During the game," he answered, watching Justin's face carefully. He appeared unphased.

Justin cocked a brow, excitement mixed with intrigue evident in his lit eyes. "I was here during that time," he pointed out, "Watching the game."

Winston nodded, "You were, and as far as anyone knows, you didn't leave until well after," he almost sighed, "Listen Justin, what exactly is it with you and this crime? It seems that you're more interested in it than the hockey game."

Justin shifted, looking anywhere but at him, "Well, it's just...Marvin and his fiancé, you know. I just thought they...weren't right for each other. I had a talk with her once. I asked her not to marry him. But she didn't listen."

A sudden clang of a puck hitting the net caught their attention, but Winston kept his gaze on Justin, watching, and listening. There was a lot more to this case than meets the eye, he knew. However, his interview with Justin had just ended, leaving him with more questions than answers.

The harsh, industrial lighting of the hockey rink painted a grave picture as Detective Winston surveyed the crime scene. The rink's security tapes corroborated Frederick's presence at the scene, even capturing a heated argument between him and Marvin. In this particular argument, Marvin was heard threatening harm to Frederick's defenceless daughter. Frederick, a curator of a local weapons museum, also held a job at the hockey rink, giving him a valid reason for being there.

Setting that evidence aside, Winston trotted towards the museum, a place Frederick frequented due to his love for antique machetes. Frederick had the responsibility of overseeing the unique collection of blades, his dedication emanating as bright as the lights above the collection.

What piqued Winston's interest though was that one of the machetes in Frederick's collection matched the description of the weapon that ended Marvin's life. Such violent usage of a machete aligned with Marvin's previous harmful behavior; aggressive threats and unbidden visits to the girls' locker room only added to the growing list of his offensive conduct. After obtaining the necessary legal papers, Winston re-examined the machetes, concluding the lethal weapon indeed came from Frederick's collection.

Taking a break from the museum, Detective Winston investigated Frederick further by questioning those who knew him. His protective behavior for his daughter was a common topic, supported further by a chilling detail given by a coworker in the hockey rink's locker rooms.

"Marvin once threatened Frederick's girl. Frederick didn't take it lightly, and they've been arguing ever since," the coworker confessed. Despite the locker rooms being an area exclusively accessed by staff with keys, Marvin had been spotted in there more times than anyone could count.

Winston's sharp gasp caught the coworkers attention, "What is it, Detective?"

"Nothing...just...let me know if you notice anything else...odd," replied Winston.

Echoes off the old lockers were the only responses he got.

With a cluttered mind flooded with information, Winston had a lot of thinking to do, miles to go before this case could be put to rest.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
When Howard was found dead in his home office, strangled by a coil of barbed wire, it fell to Detective Winston to sift through lies of the prime suspects: Eric and Priscilla.

Winston sipped his lukewarm coffee, staring at the scrawled notes in front of him. The murder of Howard wasn't a simple case. Howard, a workaholic, often spent late hours alone in his home office. This detail was well-known among the local community, and was confirmed by his visibly lit office window at night. Night after night, the sensor lights in Priscilla's driveway snapped on. The neighbor's dog howling in protest was a nightly routine in that silent suburb. The city records had also confirmed there was no power outage to explain this.

Winston spent his evening in his car, watching Priscilla's house fade into the twilight. Exactly at 11:00 PM, the lights went out. The city was at rest, but not him.

The following morning, he reached Howard's property. The land was notably fenced with barbed wire. The house felt eerily quiet for a place that was buzzing till late every night, a direct contradiction to Howard's usual late-night work routine in his office. Detective Winston crossed the threshold of the house, standing in the middle of the late man's office.

A neighbor from across the street approached him warily. Fear and curiosity in her dark eyes, she shared how she had occasionally seen Priscilla's car parked outside Howard's house. She specifically mentioned a time that coincided with the time of murder, which made Priscilla an even more interesting person of interest.

Later on, Winston paid a visit to Priscilla. She was a lean woman with sharp eyes, an indication of her military background. To his surprise, she had no alibi for the time of Howard's murder. Her familiarity with the layout of Howard's house was apparent as she effortlessly guided Winston through the house, talking about her frequent visits to this place.

Winston noted down her tidbits, like how she used to be involved in some criminal activities involving barbed wire. He, however, made no comment. She justified it by her time in the military, stating it was an easily accessible and efficient material back then.

Back at his office, Winston couldn't shake off an uneasy feeling. The constant motion-sensor light flicker, the familiarity with the house, the absence of an alibi, and neighbor's observation of her car at the crime scene... they were just pieces of a big puzzle waiting to be solved. 

"Hey Winston," a fellow officer dropped by his desk, "got yourself a late-night mystery."

But Winston just sipped his now cold cup of coffee in response. It was a long, long night ahead.

Winston exhaled a slow stream of smoke from his cigarette, staring down at the case file in front of him. Howard, dead in his own home office, secluded away in a secret crescendo of the house, known only to one person - Eric. 

Eric, a local pet groomer and the last known visitor at Howard's house, was the only one seen in the vicinity that day as confirmed by street surveillance. Winston rang the doorbell of the Pet Grooming Station, and soon a youthful man in a set of coveralls answered, his hands marked up with a variety of small scratches.

"You Eric?" Winston asked, flashing his badge.

"That's me," Eric acknowledged, offering a friendly nod.

"I understand you're the regular pet groomer for Howard?" Winston inquired.

"I am, sir,” Eric responded cordially, “I was just over at his house earlier today, grooming his pets. His office was the cleanest room; Howard always took pride in it."

Winston hummed and checked off something on his notepad. Eric, worn out, decided to sit down and pulled a diary from his pocket. Flipping through the pages, Eric showed a particular entry. It was a confession of his love for a woman named Gloria, "I've always loved this girl named Gloria. She shows me signs of affection, but she's engaged to Howard," Eric read out loud.

“You carry your work tools with you, right?” asked Winston, a note of suspicion entering his voice.

"Yes,” Eric replied, a flicker of surprise crossing his features, “I like to be prepared. I even carry fencing materials like barbed wire for temporary partitions when grooming pets."

Winston let a slow smile spread across his face. "It so happens the place where Howard was found dead was wrapped in barbed wire, with traces of pet fur on it."

"A horrible coincidence indeed," Eric responded, warily.

Winston gave a nod, buttoning up his coat. “Thank you for your time, Eric.”

“Anything for the law, Detective,” Eric said, lingering at the door until Winston drove out of sight.

“So here’s a twist for you,” Winston muttered to himself, checking off another item on his case notes and wondering about the potential romantic triangle. From the background noise of screeching pets at Eric's establishment, he drove back to Howard's crime scene, ready to sift through the evidence once again.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
When Howard was found dead in his home office, strangled by a coil of barbed wire, it fell to Detective Winston to sift through lies of the prime suspects: Eric and Priscilla.

Winston sighed as he glanced at the report of the latest murder. Howard, killed in his home office, and with barbed wire of all things. Admittedly, he wasn't an animal lover, but the fact the murderer was brazen enough to use something like that was unnerving.

Getting out of his car, he approached the home of his latest suspect, Eric. A pet groomer by trade, who Howard had hired frequently to look after his pets. The peculiar thing about Eric was not only that he used barbed wire to fence the more adventurous pets in check, but that he always carried his work tools, barbed wire included, to his clients' homes. 

A neighbor had once mentioned how often he'd seen Eric hauling his grooming tools to his van, barbed wire coils included, and he frequently overheard the sound of water running from Eric's place, leading to reports of an unusually high water bill for Eric last month. The bill was discussed by the locals, and how this pet groomer used a lot of water in his duties wasn't lost on them.

Winston knocked on the door, greeted by a man with sincere eyes and the faint smell of animal shampoo.

“You're Eric, right?” said Winston.

“That’s correct” the man replied with a friendly smile.

"And you groom pets, correct?" Winston continued.

"That's right. I love animals. Even work with barbed wire to keep the more... adventurous ones in check. People in the neighborhood could tell you that. My next-door neighbor always sees me taking my work tools, including the wire, to my clients' homes and he hears the water running as well. You know, cause of bathing and grooming."

“Hmm,..." Winston hummed, rubbing his chin thoughtfully. "You ever work at Howard's place?"

“Of course!" Eric exclaimed quickly. "Known him, his fiancee Gloria, and his pets for a while now. Have them on top of my customer list, along with a large number of other cat and dog owners.”

“Gloria?” Winston probed.

Eric's face flushed, “Yes, I've known her for years, almost ten now. I visit her often for work, and...”

"Anything else about Gloria?" Winston interrupted.

Eric paused for a moment before responding, “She’s special, Gloria. Kind to everything and everyone, she often showed me signs of warmth and kindness."

As Winston observed Eric, he noticed a notebook lying open on a nearby table. Flipping to the appointments section, he found a number of entries for cat and dog owners, confirming Eric's busy schedule. One page, however, caught his attention: a diary page with 'I love Gloria' written numerous times, speaking volumes about Eric's feelings for her.

"Thank you for your time, Eric," Winston finally said. As he headed towards the door, he turned and asked, "Howard's office, fur on the barbed wire used?"

Eric nodded. "Yes, found it quite odd. Normally, I only groom pets in their homes."

Exiting the home, he made his way back to his car, a new collection of information swirling in his head. Winston had an uneasy feeling about this Eric. He made a mental note to have Eric’s diary and customer list with a number of cat and dog owners entered into evidence. There were a lot of dots to connect and they seemed to be dancing around in his head.

The blaring sirens came to a halt as Winston arrived at where the latest gruesome killing had taken place. Howard, a man who liked his quiet and often threw himself into work, found dead in his home office. According to initial reports, the murder weapon seemed to be a strand of barbed wire. Winston proceeded towards the crime scene, trying to keep his senses sharp to any clues he might find.

Priscilla was a person of interest in the case. Tied to a string of crimes that included the use of barbed wire, she seemed more suspicious with every detail. Winston would be remiss if he didn't get all the facts about her lined up and ready. Priscilla, an ex-military personnel, stood out for her lack of an alibi during the time of murder. Winston made a note to conduct a thorough interrogation.

While going over the diagrams and photos of the scene, Winston found that Howard's property was surrounded by barbed wire fences. An odd detail to his suburban house. Witnesses - the neighbors- reported seeing Priscilla's car on multiple occasions, and explicitly during the time of the murder, at the fenced property. A regular visitor, it seemed. Priscilla had no alibi, and knew the layout of the house well.

Howard, always a reserved man, chose to spend lengthy hours alone in his home office. The numerous sightings of Priscilla at his house during these late work hours, and decisively at the time of murder, intrigued Winston. These were little crumbs, but they pointed Winston in a strong direction.

Winston pulled Priscilla in for questioning; she was not an easy nut to crack. She had a history, pervasions into criminal activities that increased her confidence in her ability to avoid capture. Murmurings of previous killings involving barbed wire whirled around her, and each successful kill reportedly fed her sense of power and precision.

Winston’s revelations grew more unnerving when he discovered that Howard, knowing too much, had threatened to turn her in to the authorities. A direct threat, a motive. Could she have killed Howard to protect her dark secrets? Unraveling Priscilla's role in this was going to be a daunting task that Winston had to muster the strength to undertake. Hidden somewhere amidst these scattered pieces of evidence was the truth, waiting to be pieced together.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the eerie silence of the swamp, Charlie's life was claimed by a crossbow, leaving Detective Winston in a murky world of deception, suspicion and the two possible culprits: Nathaniel and Bridget.

Winston, brow furrowed under the brim of his hat, flicked through a stack of papers bearing the unfortunate Charlie's name. Liaising with Charlie's lawyer revealed that Charlie had altered his will just last week, although interestingly had chosen not to inform Bridget of the adjustments.

Unlike the familiarity of his desk, even with a manila folder full of cold, hard facts, Winston found himself thinking about the case in the midst of the swamp, the location of Charlie’s demise.

Ironically, the swamp was a familiar terrain for Bridget. Before their marriage had crumbled, Bridget and Charlie used to share outdoor hobbies. Over the years, Bridget had become more than familiar with the contours and curves of the landscape. Coupled with regular sightings of her in various terrains with her crossbow, it wasn't hard to conclude that she adapted to different environments exceptionally well.

Per the information provided by some of the locals, Winston discovered that Bridget was a thanatology specialist, a discipline she studied in school. It was not every day he met someone who was an expert in understanding death and dying.

After taking a sip of his lukewarm coffee, Winston’s attention rested on another worrisome piece of information. Her business had recently gone bankrupt, and she was regularly lagging on her loan repayments.

One of her favorite pastimes coincidentally revolved around the crossbow, the same weapon which had caused Charlie his final breath. Bridget was often seen in the backyard, practicing with her crossbow, her aim true time and time again.

Winston got up from the desk, stretching as he moved towards the board full of pinned photos. He had word that Bridget had recently purchased a new set of crossbow bolts. Coupled with her financial trappings, it felt ominously grim.

Yet what was intriguing about Bridget was her constant voracious appetite for books she often purchased from the bookstore. More often than not, the subjects of these books would smoothly slide into regular conversation with Bridget. And she made no attempts to hide these books. An array of them can easily be found nesting on the shelves in her living room.

Winston leaned against the board, squinting at a photo of Bridget, crossbow in her capable hands in a rugged, unfamiliar terrain. This was a standard investigation; he had to remember that, just like any other case. But then, death by crossbow point in a swamp was far from standard.

As the mire of the swamp clung to his boots, Winston added gloves and a mask to his grim ensemble. His sharp eyes darted to and fro, the paleness of Charlie's lifeless body in strong contrast to the murky waters. He sighed softly, letting his eyes linger on the scene, before turning his attention from the horrific sight to the task at hand. 

His first item of business? Nathaniel. Winston was intrigued by Nathaniel, a seemingly innocuous garbage man if you didn't know better. But he was already fully aware of the man's impressive archery prowess. Winston could easily recall the then-scrawny Nathaniel from their younger days, confidently hitting bullseyes with eerie accuracy in local competitions.

A few steps away from the trashcan, exactly where Nathaniel usually invoked curiosity among his neighbors by meticulously sorting his collection, stood the very man himself.

"How've you been, Nathaniel?" Winston shined a polite, professional smile.

"Can't complain, can't complain." Nathaniel responded, shaking his head slightly. "This job, being out there collecting garbage every morning never misses a day, has its moments."

Winston's memory was unfailing. It prompted him to remember that, disturbingly often when he saw Nathaniel in Charlie's vicinity, he was rummaging through Charlie's garbage. He'd heard Charlie say on multiple occasions that Nathaniel had been stealing things from his bin, which Charlie once confronted him about publicly. More compelling was that Charlie had reported valuables missing from his home coincidentally on days that lined up with Nathaniel's collection rounds. Winston's mind echoed these questionable correlations, "+You're certainly involved in your work, Nathaniel. Find anything of interest - something out of the ordinary maybe?"

Nathaniel tried not to wince, "Just daily discard. But sometimes, even useful ones. The other day I even found a crossbow, still in perfect condition, just tossed away."

Winston made a note of this in his mind, knowing that Nathaniel also held a hunting license. With his background in archery, a crossbow would certainly be of interest to him. 

Sensing a shift in Nathaniel's demeanor, Winston asked, "Didn't Charlie make a scene about his missing items, that time?"

Nathaniel exhaled in resignation. "He did... confronted me in front of everyone," he revealed, his voice sounding restrained. He focused his gaze intensely on the refuse nearby. "And that day... that day he was found dead, it was just another workday for me. I had my morning round, like every other day."

As Winston prepared to leave, he asked one more question. "Just one thing Nathaniel...your route includes the swamp area as well, correct?"

Nathaniel glanced at the detective, confirming, "Yes, the swamp isn't too far from the regular route, it's included."

With that, Winston shooed Nathaniel back to his routine and watched as he slowly disappeared. As his boots squished back towards the swamp, he couldn't shake off an eerie feeling about Nathaniel – the ordinary garbage man with a mix of archery skills, hunting licenses, and curious finds. For now, though, the murky waters of the swamp commanded his attention. At least until tomorrow.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the eerie silence of the swamp, Charlie's life was claimed by a crossbow, leaving Detective Winston in a murky world of deception, suspicion and the two possible culprits: Nathaniel and Bridget.

Winston sighed, coffee in hand, as he observed Nathaniel from across the yard. Nathaniel was methodically dissecting an entire neighborhood's refuse, picking valuable items that seemed to spark his interest from the detritus he sifted through. On Nathaniel’s trash run, he had picked up a wooden stick that sharply resembled a crossbow.

“Hey Nathaniel, are you a huntsman by any chance?” Winston asked walking up to him. Nathaniel replied, “Well, yes, as a matter of fact, I am. I have a hunting license, and I even won a few archery contests back in the day.” His eyes twinkled at the memories. Winston nodded, keeping any additional comments to himself. 

On the way back from their brief conversation, Winston noted something unusual for a garbage collector: an open novel, placed neatly beside Nathaniel’s bagged lunch. A genre-specific novel no less; its contents filled with murder and mayhem. Meeting Nathaniel's gaze, he nodded towards the book and asked, "Reading on duty?" Nathaniel chuckled and said, "Aye, there's no policy against it, and the higher-ups don't seem to mind. It often makes for good conversation with coworkers. I often bring these novels to work as well. They come in handy during those discussions ironically."

Intrigued, Winston checked with some of Nathaniel’s colleagues later that day. What he found was surprising - they all confirmed Nathaniel was quite the connoisseur when it came to discussing murder plots, often using his thriller novels as references. Oddly enough, he rarely brought any other type of books, always favoring murder and mayhem it seemed.

As Winston's day wore on, he remembered a report he had seen in the precinct earlier, filed by none other than Charlie. Charlie had reported missing valuables, specifically on the days Nathaniel would have his trash collection route.

Winston also recalled a secondhand report about a public confrontation between Nathaniel and Charlie. The report stated that Charlie had "called out" Nathaniel for stealing his valuables from his trash. Piecing it together, Winston realized that Charlie's accusations and the missing items correlated with Nathaniel's collection days. He sighed, wondering if the rumors held any weight.

Remembering another piece of information he picked up earlier, he roamed to the back alley adjacent to Charlie's house. Nathaniel was indeed seen sifting through Charlie's trash on multiple occasions, acquiring items of value. This linked well with what the confrontation and the report seemed to suggest. However, none of this established Nathaniel as Charlie's killer.

As Winston drove back to the precinct, he couldn’t shake off the circular puzzle that had begun to form in his mind, a puzzle as murky and enigmatic as the swamp that held Charlie's lifeless body. But his instincts had served him well before, and he was determined to see the case through, wherever it may lead.

Having a quick glance at his notes, Winston's eyes lingered on some key details about his prime suspect in this murder case. Bridget, the ex-wife of Charlie, who was without an evident alibi for the time of the murder. Charlie's life ended tragically in the heart of the swamp, a place where he loved to visit, quite often alone. He was taken down by a lethal crossbow bolt. Recalling that Charlie had changed his will last week without telling Bridget, Winston felt a twinge of unease. He shook his head, massaging his tired temples before heading off to where Bridget was staying.

He found Bridget in her backyard, busy practicing with her crossbow—an activity she was ardently committed to, despite varied environments. Her talented handling of the weapon suggested much experience, most likely from her hunting trips to the swamp with her ex-husband, Charlie. Lying next to her crossbow was a pack of new bolts, recently purchased, Winston pieced together. 

"Bridget?" Winston asked, stepping forward. 

"That would be me," she replied, setting her crossbow down on a nearby tree stump.

"Bridget, it seems like you knew Charlie would be at the swamp the day he was killed," he pointed, maintaining eye contact whilst pulling out his notepad.

"Yeah, we used to fish and hunt out there a lot. Charlie loved that place. Why?" she asked guardedly.

Ignoring her question, he inquired again. "It says you've been defaulting on your loan repayments lately and your business declared bankruptcy recently. What else aren't you telling me, Bridget?"

Looking both surprised and annoyed, she retorted by defending herself, "I have nothing to hide."

Winston merely nodded, scribbling a few notes down before leaving Bridget in the backyard next to her fresh set of crossbow bolts. The wheels of the investigation were starting to turn and Winston intended to ride the momentum until he found Charlie's killer.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the winding passages of a labyrinth, Lauren meets her untimely death by nail gun, pulling Detective Winston into a complex maze of lies and danger where Rose and Aubrey become his primary suspects.


Winston sat in his dimly lit office, peering over the case details. The name Lauren frequented his mind as he evaluated the circumstances of her death. It was a unique scene to say the least, a murder inside a labyrinth, with a nail gun as the murder weapon of choice.

His focus then diverted to the name that was on everyone's lips: Rose. She was Lauren's stepsister and her profession stood out to him the most. Rose was a carpenter; she was often required to read blueprints for her job, and had comprehensive knowledge about nail guns due to her regular use of them at work. As it happened, the blueprint of the labyrinth where the body was found was posted at her jobsite. An interesting coincidence, Winston thought, but he knew better than to jump to conclusions.

Rose's gang involvement made matters more complicated. As a member of a local gang that took their reputation seriously, she found herself enmeshed in scenarios where respect was the ultimate currency. Winston remembered hearing about a notorious gathering of the gang where Lauren had called Rose a loser. To publicly humiliate her in front of her fellow gang members like that had not been taken lightly. What bothered Winston was that despite Rose being present at a community event nearby, no one noticed her in the labyrinth that day.

Conviction settled within Winston. He needed to talk to Rose. Grabbing his coat, he exited the office, his mind reflecting the image of the carpenter, wrapped in the complexities of Lauren's murder. Little did he know, the clues were only beginning to unfold.

Detective Winston put away the photos of the crime scene he was investigating. The labyrinth where Lauren was found, held a certain eerie mystique to it. He began by interviewing the suspect, Aubrey.

Walking into the office of Aubrey was like walking into a different time period. The room was grand and ornate, filled with all types of frames and decor, managed by none other than Aubrey himself, the boss of the esteemed business.

Winston started the conversation careful not to rush. "You designed the labyrinth?" he asked, nodding.

A look of pride crossed Aubrey's face, "Yes, indeed. I even supervised its construction."

Winston casually inquired, "And the labyrinth is part of the business property, I presume?"

"Most definitely. It's a showcase, so to speak," Aubrey said.

Winston continued the conversation but his attention was drawn by a box in a display case on Aubrey's desk. The box was labeled "Keepsake". "What's in the box?" he asked.

Aubrey looked slightly taken aback before he smiled, "Oh, that. It's a lock of hair from someone who owed me. This person owed me and this is my keepsake," he admitted with an air of nonchalance.

A brief silence followed. Breaking it, Winston continued, "The labyrinth. Pretty difficult to navigate, I assume. Any blueprints or maps for it?"

Aubrey half shook his head, "The labyrinth is an enigma, detective, designed to challenge and confound. There are no public maps or blueprints for it."

Winston couldn't help but notice a defaced picture in Aubrey's collection. It was a photo of a once close friend, the eyes had been scratched out thoroughly. "What happened to the picture?" Winston asked. 

Aubrey didn't take a second to respond, "A moment of rage. I was angry at betrayal by an old friend. I scratched the eyes out and after the argument, I put it back in there." 

Later on, Winston found out about a whispered overheard conversation Aubrey had about Lauren's betrayal as Aubrey was outside Lauren's house. Apparently, Aubrey had overheard a conversation between Lauren and a competitor. This lead to the argument and defacement of the photo.

After the conversation with Aubrey, Winston got a hint towards Aubrey's character. Before he left, Winston asked, "You have access to that labyrinth, correct?"

"Of course," confirmed Aubrey, "I have master keys to all parts of my property."

It was after Winston visited Lauren's residence that he found copies of confidential business documents clearly indicating her plans of betrayal. Lauren had planned to sell secrets to a known rival. 

"This case," muttered Winston, "is starting to look like a veritable labyrinth itself."
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the winding passages of a labyrinth, Lauren meets her untimely death by nail gun, pulling Detective Winston into a complex maze of lies and danger where Rose and Aubrey become his primary suspects.


Winston was feeling the pressure as he approached Aubrey's home located adjacent to her business site. He had known her for a while in the professional world - She was a respected, even renowned, contractor. Every evening, after an exhausting day at work, it was a common sight to see Aubrey trudging home, her hands loaded with tools from a difficult day of managing construction projects. Among all the tools, the heavy-duty nail guns were a constant companion. Aubrey was always working on projects that involved a lot of nailing, such as erecting wooden framings or installing roofing and siding. 

"Detective Winston," Aubrey greeted him from the porch, clasping her hands stained with a year's worth of construction grime, "What brings you to my neck of the woods?" 

Winston cleared his throat as he glanced at the construction tools visibly scattered around her house. Nail guns, power saws - everything you would find in a contractor's toolkit. As a person who often worked on structures from scratch, nail guns were typically a requirement due to their versatility. 

"Got a moment?" Winston asked, trying to keep the gravity out of his voice. Aubrey agreed and led him to her home office, which interestingly, was doubling as a toolshed. He once again couldn't help but notice a few nail guns among the equipment at her home. A professional necessity or a personal preference, he wondered. 

"It's about Lauren," Winston began. Aubrey's face stiffened. "We found confidential documents at her house. Seems she was planning something... something that involved your company."

Aubrey looked surprised momentarily, but then her face settled into a serious expression. She admitted to overhearing a conversation between Lauren and McDowell, her rival, confirming Winston's suspicions. 

Aubrey's company was known for creating unique structures, like the complex labyrinth where Lauren was found dead. Aubrey had designed and supervised its construction. And since it was situated within her business property, Aubrey always maintained full access to it. However, much to Winston's surprise, the labyrinth had no public blueprints or maps, as Aubrey preferred to keep it unique. 

As Winston left Aubrey's home, he knew he still had a lot of facts to untangle, not least of which was Lauren's apparent attempt to betray Aubrey's trust by selling confidential business secrets to a competitor. But with Aubrey's insights, he was ready to dig deeper into the nuanced maze of Lauren's mysterious death.

Winston sat in silence at the edge of the chaotic crime scene, the labyrinth had become a monstrous cavity of mystery, with its winding tunnels and disorienting dead ends. What had happened to Lauren was no less perplexing, and one name kept echoing through the investigators' speculation: Rose.

Rose, known for her impeccable memory and experience in acting, was a prominent figure in this tightly wound community. She was always present at functions and events, as noted at the most recent meeting, a gathering Winston had attended himself not too long ago.

Not everyone was gentle with their words that day, Winston knew too well. Lauren, the deceased, had thrown around a few insults, Rose being one of her victims. She had been called a loser in front of the whole gathering. Rose came from a gang where respect was paramount, and such humiliation did not sit light on her shoulders, but she had somehow managed to remain unnoticed in the labyrinth later.

Something caught Winston's interest – Rose's fondness for movies with intense, dramatic scenes. Late at night, from her room's closed door, her family often heard the telltale sound of violent movies emanating. The detective filed that away, nodding as he considered the implications.

Rose worked in construction, where reading blueprints was second nature, and interestingly, the blueprint of the labyrinth was accessible at her workplace. Winston noted this with a measure of unsettled interest. After dinner, Rose would often retreat to her room and stay locked in.

As he reviewed these facts, Winston could already feel the pressure building, and the all-consuming labyrinth of the case looming before him, his mind working tirelessly to map out where his next steps would take him.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the quiet tranquility of a mosque, Erika met her untimely death by a sickle, and it's up to the astute Detective Winston to shine light on the dark secrets guarded by suspects Aubrey and Garry.


Detective Winston checked his wrist watch unenthusiastically. As the hands of time slothfully crawled to seven, he began his shift for the evening. Erika's friend and consistent prayer companion, Fatima, waited anxiously in his office. She insisted on stressing that Aubrey, their mutual acquaintance, had been spotted at the mosque earlier that day during evening prayer, a place Aubrey was not customarily seen. 

Winston slowly hummed in acknowledgment, checking his files as Fatima continued her tale. Erika, in fact, wasn’t just a friend of the thriving museum curator but an investor in his flailing business. Fatima explained that Aubrey, despite attempts to keep his operations afloat via high-interest loans, had been struggling to maintain financial stability. In passing, Fatima mentioned that a banker friend of Aubrey's had told her that the repayments on Aubrey's loans were going to double next month. 

Winston mulled over his thoughts, refraining from allowing his suspicions to sprinkle into the conversation. Instead, he queried about Erika's visits to the mosque. Dabbing at the water forming in her eyes, Fatima confirmed that Erika dutifully attended every evening prayer without fail. Was it possible then she had met her untimely end during one of these visits?

Later, as Winston paced through the office corridors, he revisited the mosque's security footage. Indeed, as per Fatima's earlier account, Aubrey could be seen entering the mosque around the expected time frame. 

Still thoroughly perplexed, Winston visited the museum across the street. Aubrey stood there, overseeing the preservation and acquisition of various historical artifacts, his primary duty as a museum curator. As he strolled around the exhibits, he observed a collection of historical farming tools hauled in for display, including a rather menacing collection of sickles. 

"Aubrey," Winston began, levelly maintaining eye contact, "Unusual setting for you, the mosque. Isn't it?"

Aubrey looked up from his inspection of an ancient agriculture tool, "I go here and there, detective,"  he replied curtly. 

Watching Aubrey's carefully calibrated handling of the tools, Winston quizzed him about it. "Last year," Aubrey responded, "The museum held a special exhibit on historical farming tools. I took a workshop to handle them appropriately."

"Impressive." Winston said before wrapping up the brief discussion, knowing he needed to revisit the mysterious circumstances surrounding Erika's death.

Winston stepped into the bustling lobby of the premier hotel. He scanned the crowded workspace before his gaze settled on a slender man behind the concierge desk, busily attending to the guests' requests. It was Garry, the hotel's highly appreciated concierge. 

His co-workers always found it peculiar though, how much detail Garry remembered about the guests and their desires, almost uncomfortably precise details were remembered and shared more than just what was needed for his job. Garry had a knack for remembering little details from conversations, often times, trivia from the recent documentaries he watched. Winston overheard him regurgitating facts from a documentary about the dangers of farming equipment to a slightly bewildered guest. This troubling affinity for detail chimed with the meticulous calendar filled with documentary premiere dates that Winston found after a quick scan of Garry's desk. 

Winston decided to strike up conversation with Garry, who seemed eager to take a break from the steady stream of guests. 

"Nice cut on the lawn on my way in here," Winston said,
"Comes with experience," Garry responded with a grin, "Spent years on my farm before this gig, manicuring my own lawn. Lawn care, tool maintenance, harvest, I've done it all. The sickle was always my tool of choice. After all, I’ve been given the task of maintaining all the garden tools in this place, including the sickle."

The way he talked about the sickle, it was clear that he respected the tool, but also was well aware of the dangerous potency from his past farming experience. But the way Garry straightened from leaning on the desk, his light chatter becoming scarce when the name of the victim, Erika, was brought up, caught Winston's attention. 

"Erika...she did say something about...," Garry hesitated, his uncomfortable gaze flicking around, "...about planning to report my past criminal records to the cops. Gave me real shivers, that girl."

Prior to these events, it was common knowledge among the staff that Garry adjusted his work hours to suit his documentary schedule. But the notable changes during the days following Erika's announcement were peculiar. They were stranger still, considering Garry was seen bustling about, polishing tools and manicuring the hotel lawn on the day of Erika's murder.

Winston left the hotel, mulling over the conversation back at the hotel. There was no denying his past experience with the sickle, but Winston found it hard to believe that he’d go so far as to kill. His already gnarled past filled with criminal activities now tangled with Erika's death and his sudden unease when she planned to report him. A mystery laced with curiosities, Winston had to tread carefully.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the quiet tranquility of a mosque, Erika met her untimely death by a sickle, and it's up to the astute Detective Winston to shine light on the dark secrets guarded by suspects Aubrey and Garry.


Winston eyed the iron-wrought cemetery gates, exploring their intricate patterns in the early morning before Aubrey, the museum curator, would come to unlock them. Aubrey held the keys to these gates with as much reverence as she held the amber locket around her neck.

Even at the dusk, the gates remained locked until every morning, like clockwork, Aubrey would approach. Her eyes filled with a sense of duty, Winston could see the earnest expression on Aubrey's face as she carefully turned keys in the heavy iron lock, thus breaking the morning lock-up routine.

In the midst of observing this routine, Winston recalled a conversation he had with a museum associate. Aubrey had indeed gone through a weapon-handling workshop for their historical farming tools exhibit. Among the overlapping news and chatter, the museum's collection of farming tools, including old, rusted sickles, had stood out.

The garden surrounding Aubrey's museum served as a commendable background for her tea dates with Erika. Erika, as a major stakeholder in the museum, had been more than a frequent visitor. That curious connection kept popping up in Winston's head more often than not.

Out of the corner of his eye, Winston observed Aubrey lost in her thoughts. She was walking along the tombstones, meticulously studying and reciting the names engraved upon them. Perhaps it was her way of remembering the past, or maybe just a strange way to unwind.

There was no one else around, and in the lonesome tranquillity of the graveyard, Aubrey could be seen talking, possibly reciting, to herself. It was a loner's soliloquy, as if she was pouring her secrets over the tombstones just to be buried once again.

Winston could still remember overhearing Aubrey's desperate call for high-interest loans to keep her museum afloat. The economic strain on the museum's budget hadn't escaped Aubrey. His ears rang with her words saying that the repayments on these loans were going to double next month. That, coupled with her responsibility for the acquisition and care of items in the museum's collection, was enough to pressurize any soul.

As Winston began to tread back towards the unmarked, black investigation car; he noted the quiet cemetery's rusty gates lock again. Every morning, the same routine was played out, the morning locking was now giving way to another day's activities as the wheels started to crunch the gravel beneath, Winston took one last glance towards Aubrey, his suspect and the harbinger of the day's sacred silence.

Under the intimidating grandeur of the mosque structure, Winston, the detective, sat on a wooden bench, meticulously observing Garry as he was tending the lawn near the west wing. Garry, the only concierge of the mosque, was wiping the brow of his forehead. Beads of sweat flicking off his hand with each move, the masculine, meticulous manner with which he manoeuvered the garden sickle on the greenery, shaped each shrub with an artistic finesse. It was easy to tell he was an old hand with garden tools; his professional grip spoke volumes of his previous life as a farmer. The sickle was a potentially dangerous tool, and Garry's familiarity with it hinted at his past.

"Hard at work I see," Winston observed as he approached the sole handyman. Garry looked up, his eyes narrowing in on the unfamiliar face. "And who might you be?" he asked with a hint of caution in his voice. 

"Winston. Detective Winston," he introduced himself, tucking the badge away as Garry nodded in understanding. Winston spoke again, "I believe you were the only staff member on duty during the time of Erika’s murder. I need to chat with you, Garry."

Erika before, her tragic end, had stumbled upon Garry's criminal records, she expressed her intention to report this to the authorities, making the significance of this conversation unmatched. From the jittery pick-me-up in his darting eyes, it was as though Garry was aware of Erika's intentions and his own past taunting his present.

"Erika happened to find an unfortunate ending in this room behind me," Detective Winston finally broke the silence, pointing in the direction of a closed entrance, "A room, the keys to which only you have, if I'm not wrong." He had leaves no room for doubt about Garry’s exclusive control over those keys.

Garry's attempt to maintain cool was crumbling as the conversation marched ahead straight onto him. "I just mind my own business, help out the folks around here," he defended himself, “The keys to all rooms in the mosque, they are part of my job, not my involvement.”

Winston watched him, not giving away that he knew more than what he was putting into words. As Garry looked away, trying to conceal his anxiety, Winston picked up his hat, excusing himself for the moment. The concierge, the previous criminal, the executor of garden manicuring, the only gatekeeper to Erika’s death room, his presence was crucial to the puzzle surrounding Erika's horrific end. A puzzle that was missing some critical pieces. Anonymously, he decided that he'd be observing a bit more of Mr. Garry and his connection to the late Erika.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the neon glow of a laser tag arena, Jacqueline's life is abruptly ended by snake venom, leaving Detective Winston with two suspects - Abigail and Veronica - and a most unusual murder mystery to solve.

The eerie glow of the black light cast long, distorted shadows across the laser tag arena as Winston stepped forward, surveying the peculiar scene of Jacqueline's demise. Normally, such places teemed with just the right amount of carefree chaos, but today, it was grimly silent.

In his hands were the materials concerning a woman named Abigail, who played host to a series of intriguing coincidences. She had been present in the very same laser tag room as Jacqueline when the fatal incident occurred, and rightly so - she was a volunteer for the charity event hosted by this venue. The fact that no other individuals - other than the unfortunate victim and Abigail - had gained entry to the room at the moment in question did arouse some intrigue.

The detective proceeded to visit the local zoo, intending to interrogate Abigail. It was here that she worked delicately within the reptile exhibit. During the conversation, Abigail let slip that she had recently been to a seminar on venom extraction, a fact that aligned ominously well with the fact that the lethal dose of venom involved in the case was sourced from a snake. Winston made sure to note in the ledgers that the zoo housed a few snakes famed for packing some notably potent venom.

As he delved deeper into Abigail's profile, he discovered previously unknown challenges. The lady seemed keen to keep her financial struggle under wraps. Her house payments had been consistently late - he quickly connected it to a recent incident wherein she had gone to pawn a valuable family heirloom. 

During a casual digging into Abigail's cyber history, Winston discovered that she had been looking up life insurance policies - how they unfolded, and how they reciprocated after the policy holder's unfortunate demise. Once more, a circumstance which had the potential to open up some conjecture: Jacqueline had, indeed, changed her life insurance policy beneficiary a few months back, and the new beneficiary was none other than - you guessed it.

“Life’s expensive, isn't it?” Winston mentioned, trying to coax her into admitting to her fiscal struggles. Abigail just nodded, her gaze distant.

Finishing his conversation, Winston decided it was time to leave. Just as he was walking away, Abigail called out to him, pointing to a serpent slithering in a terrarium. She began to relay some information about snake venom, the extraction process, and how surprisingly easy it would be to perform such an extraction.

Stories were quickly unraveled, intertwining closer than he initially assumed. As Winston walked away from the zoo, he couldn't help but notice the unshakeable belief that the logic of the world had its way of turning in full circles. After all, Jacqueline's team had signed up for the charity event at the laser tag arena... the very event that led her to her untimely end.

Winston expelled a cloud of smoke from his lips as he gazed at the neon-lit steel doors of the laser tag arena. The once lively hub of fun and games now secured by crime scene tape, a grim murder mystery looming ominously around every corner.

By the entrance, a young singer by the name of Veronica was nervously waiting, her fingers fiddling with the fringes of her coat as Winston approached. There was a peculiar untouchability about her, evident in how she retreated to the corners and refused to attend social events, preferring instead to stay home practicing singing and performing, focusing her waking hours on her career.

"Singer, eh?" Winston began, keen on learning more about this aloof character, "Must be a very exhausting lifestyle."

"Uh-huh," she answered, her focus still on the ground. "No time to really get to know anyone, not even a close friend."

Her response reminded Winston of what her friends had reported: Veronica's constant rejection when they tried to deepen their friendship with her. It was clear she had no time for love or friendship in her hectic life.

Before this occupation though, Winston had learned, Veronica used to work at a snake farm in her younger years. Intriguingly, she even performed at a show near the snake farm just a week before this murder had occurred. 

The snake farm, he had discovered, reported a missing venomous snake days after Veronica's show. This became even more intriguing considering Veronica's unusual interest in snake venom - she had written a research paper on it once.

Veronica's social encounters were fraught with tension, particularly with Jacqueline. Winston recalled hearing about their argument at a party centered around their differing nationalities. Veronica had publicly insulted Jacqueline's nationality during a performance too, a clear result of her prejudice which she had made public on more than one occasion. 

"What happened with Jacqueline at the party, Veronica? Seems like you two had a fallout?" Winston asked.

Veronica shifted uncomfortably. "It was just a disagreement," she stammered. "She didn’t understand my point of view and…" her voice trailed off.

"You made it public too, during your performance?" Winston probed. He could see Veronica was taken aback, but didn't flinch.

"Look, my insults were directed at her nationality,” Veronica snapped, her filters slipping. “But that doesn’t mean I'm a… you know."

Winston nodded. This was a detective's job after all, to uncover the stories behind the stories, regardless of how inexcusable they might sound.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the neon glow of a laser tag arena, Jacqueline's life is abruptly ended by snake venom, leaving Detective Winston with two suspects - Abigail and Veronica - and a most unusual murder mystery to solve.

Winston sifted through scraps of evidence, photos, and notes strewn across his desk. Jacqueline, a big fan of a certain singer, Veronica, was his latest case, a priority due to the unusual circumstances surrounding her death - snake venom, of all things, at a laser tag arena concert, no less. A concert that shockingly happened to be on the very day of her murder.

A flier of Veronica's concert caught his eye, purple lasers splashed across the front. It had been widely promoted online - Veronica herself had announced it on her social media accounts. 

Veronica's social media had been a hotbed of activity ever since she had publicly insulted Jacqueline's nationality during a recent performance, causing several heated public altercations both online and at the arena due to this prejudice. It caused quite the stir on the internet.

Remembering the online fuss, Winston did some digging and arranged a meeting with Veronica via her manager. 

"Hello Detective, how can I help you?", Veronica asked. Her songwriter's pen was twirling between her fingers absentmindedly.

"I'm on the Jacqueline case", Winston answered stoically.

A flicker of emotion crossed Veronica's face, "I remember her...We had an argument at a party...about our nationalities." She avoided Winston's gaze.

"Hmm, those racial tensions caused quite a frenzy both at your shows and on social media. Is that correct?" Winston pointedly asked. Veronica’s mouth twisted, but she said nothing.

Winston changed course, "You used to work at a snake farm, isn't that right?"

"Yes,” Veronica replied nervously. “It was indeed, and would you imagine the irony, where I performed a week before Jacqueline's murder. They called later saying some venomous snake was missing."

"Interesting," muttered Winston. "You also penned a research paper about snake venoms, is that right?"

Veronica looked genuinely surprised, "Yes, how did you know?"

"I find it important to know about people I'm investigating. I also know that Jacqueline was a big fan of your music."

With that, he wrapped up the interview, leaving Veronica a little perplexed. Back at the precinct, he sifted through the scattered notes and typed up his report. Nothing was solved yet, but the pieces were moving into their respective slots.

Detective Winston flipped through the dossier. The laser tag arena was usually a place of fun, but now it was marked by tragedy -- Jacqueline's death. Abigail was the last person in the room with Jacqueline. She had been there volunteering for a charity event, with Jacqueline's team participating in the event. The severity of the situation felt at odds with the colorful neon lights illuminating the fluorescent walls and synthetic turf. 

He walked into the arena, noting the silence that hung in the air. He recalled the fact that the owner could hardly give him any insight given that he was preoccupied at his convenience store during the night shift. Winston checked the store's transaction records, Abigail had indeed been here in the laser tag arena, her payment indicated her presence. Abigail had also been involved with the reptile exhibit at the local zoo; he was also informed of a recently attended seminar on venom extraction. That little detail felt oddly chilling in the context of the events. 

Abigail's neighbor, when questioned, told him about his nocturnal TV watching pastime. His enjoyment of late-night soap operas inadvertently gave him a clear view of her door, consistently noting Abigail's comings and goings, her odd hours, and her solitary existence. 

He took a trip down to the zoo. It was awash with excited children and worn-out parents. A small sign heralded the reptile house as of particular interest, with potent venom snakes prolifically cited. A zookeeper mentioned a few offhanded comments Abigail had made about how venom extraction wasn't so difficult, it gave Winston pause. 

As he left, the shocking reality hit him - notably one fact, no one else had entered the laser tag room at the time of the event. Abigail and Jacqueline were the only two in the room. There was still more to be done, more evidence to be collected.

"Where were you when Jacqueline was bitten by a snake, Abigail?" He asked in his careful detective's tone. Abigail laughed nervously, her eyes darted around before landing on him again.

"I've told you, I was in the main lobby." She replied, folding her arms protectively over her chest. "Look, detective, I work at a zoo. The reptiles are my job, not some kind of hobby, okay?" 

They had wrapped up their conversation, and he was left with some threads of information that were yet to be woven into a full picture. It was time to follow the clues, to unravel the tightly woven mystery around the tragic end of Jacqueline.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the heart of the rainforest, Jesse meets his gruesome end by a lawnmower, leaving Detective Winston embarked on a puzzling quest with suspects - Sam and Steve.

Winston looked over the notes that had been placed on his desk, details about Jesse, a kid he had been killed by a lawnmower in a rainforest during a school trip. Sighing, he prepared himself to go and speak to Sam, a schoolmate of Jesse with a connection to landscaping tools.

Arriving at "Green Leaves Landscaping", Winston was greeted by the bustling noise of various gardening equipment being operated for demonstrations and repairs. He looked around, noting that this place even had lawnmowers, one in particular stood out.

He was introduced to Sam. The young man, not much older than Jesse, who seemed jittery and nervous. No doubt upset about his friend's death. 

"Sam, right?" Winston asked, to which the young man just nodded. 

"Bit of a strange question, but do you know how to operate a lawnmower?" Winston asked.

A slight nod from Sam confirmed it, "Yeah, on top of that I passed my course in operating heavy machinery with distinction last summer. I know my way around from lawnmowers to bulldozers." 

Winston continued with a gentle but probing conversation, leading to Sam mentioning the school field trip to the rainforest that had turned tragic. This sparked another question from Winston. 

"Anyone else in that rainforest, apart from your school group?" The answer was negative.

The conversation took a dramatic turn when Sam admitted to finding some inappropriate texts between Jesse and his girlfriend on her phone, showing them to Winston. 

"And she admitted to it?" Winston pursued, brows furrowed. "Yes, she confessed when confronted." Sam's voice choked up a little.

Taking a mental step back, Winston continued with his questions, "Your father owns this place?" 

Sam's hand gestured around the landscape store run by his father, "Yeah, been helping him around whenever I'm free."

They chatted for a couple more minutes before Winston thanked Sam for his time and left, informing him that they might need to speak again. He reflected on what he'd learned, about Jesse's cheating, Sam’s landscaping connection and distinction-honored ability to operate heavy machinery. The facts were taking shape in a complex web, beginning to form a picture but with still much to be discovered.

Winston adjusted his fedora and walked into Steve's study in the local synagogue, filled with ancient religious texts, some open and spread out in front of Steve. Steve looked like a man deep in thought, his eyes fixated on the book in front of him. 

"Mind if I interrupt, Rabbi Steve?" Winston asked, interrupting the tranquility. 

"Detective Winston," Steve acknowledged without lifting his eyes. His voice reflected his years, a baritone stained with wisdom. 

"I understand you were meant to be at a number of religious events, which this community is known for, but it appears you were missing in action?" Winston probed lightly, trying to placate the simmering tension he could already sense. 

"I've been studying, Detective. These ancient religious texts are complicated and require my full attention, and I couldn't divide it between them and the ritualistic gatherings." Steve finally looked up, his gaze piercing through Winston.

Steve's intense lifestyle of a lot of reading and self-study was no secret to the detective. This was his daily routine.

"I understand." Winston pulled out his notepad, shifting in his seat. "You regularly volunteer for the forest clean-ups, correct?" 

"Every chance I get," Steve responded, his volunteer spirit evident in his voice. The rain forest thundered just beyond the confines of Steve's synagogue, a song of life against the urban creep. A song that often played the backdrop for Steve's volunteer efforts.

"Yes, I recall there was a cleanup event scheduled for the exact time of Jesse's murder," Winston commented, but left the sentence hanging.

A palpable silence filled the room.

Switching topics, Winston began to inquire about their rival businesses, "Seems like things are going pretty well for Jesse and his lawn care business, while yours seems to be losing steam. In fact, it seems like Jesse planned to undercut your business."

Steve's face twitched slightly at the mention of Jesse. "It's a free market, Detective."

"It is," Winston nodded, "Jesse seems to be gaining a lot of new clients recently." Steve's expression remained unfazed "Quite rapidly, actually. And at the same time, you're losing a bunch of yours.”

"Coincidence," Steve shrugged it off.

"Is it? Or do you suspect Jessie was intentionally stealing your client base?" Winston asked, knowing that Jesse undercutting his rival's price wasn't helping Steve a great deal.

"Talk to the forest, Detective," Steve sighed. “I have more pressing matters to attend to,” Steve said finishing the conversation. 

As Winston got up to leave, he asked off-handedly, "Was the synagogue typically open during those religious events?"

"Yes," Steve confirmed. "It was open to all."

"Thank you for your time, Rabbi Steve," Winston offered a curt nod and left Steve to his ancient texts requiring deep concentration, and shadows while the rainforest sang beyond.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the heart of the rainforest, Jesse meets his gruesome end by a lawnmower, leaving Detective Winston embarked on a puzzling quest with suspects - Sam and Steve.

Detective Winston stood at the edge of the rainforest, reviewing his notes. The scene was grim, even for a seasoned detective. The body of Jesse, a young boy, had been found. The murder weapon, found near his body, was a lawnmower, an odd choice for a murder weapon, especially in a rainforest.
