Taken by surprise, she nodded and softly said, “Yes.”

"So you were in love with him too, Miss Gloria?” Winston asked. Gloria looked at him in shock but after a few moments of silence, nodded again. 

"Thank you for your time, Miss Gloria,” Winston said, standing up to leave.

As he exited “Slice & Dice,” he noticed a pile of promotional meat cleavers right by the door. They were a symbol of the band, he deduced, something they handed out to fans at their events.

Regardless of the peculiar nature of this case, he had to remain focused. There were facts to be processed, people to be questioned, and justice awaited. After all, he had a solid hand and now, it was time to play it.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the aftermath of a devastating home explosion that claims the life of Angela, seasoned Detective Winston hones in on two prime suspects: Patrick and Alvin.

Detective Winston grimly regarded the charred remains of Angela's home, considering the pieces of evidence. Home explosions were not commonly dealt with in his line of work, though he knew very well that such explosives were often used in demolitions. 

With such knowledge, he was reminded of a local surfing instructor who also took part in an unconventional part-time job that would put him in frequent touch with explosives, training weekly on handling and disposal. This wasn't his usual surfing job but his part-time work as a demolition worker. This was no doubt, Patrick.

Finding his interview notes with Patrick, Winston decided it was time to speak with him again. Winston had known Patrick through his work, not because he surfed but because of his other role in demolition, an occupation that naturally involved a great deal of work with explosives.

Winston set off to the beach in search of Patrick, eventually spotting him as he was patiently teaching a young boy how to ride the waves. "Patrick!" he called out to him.

Recognizing Winston, the man navigated back to shore on his surfboard with a practised ease. "Detective Winston," he greeted, wiping the saltwater off his face. "How can I help you?"

"Just a few questions," Winston replied. He opened his notebook to a page of carefully penned notes about Patrick's financial troubles. "I heard that you've been having some trouble... getting into a failed investment, left with a sizeable debt?”

Patrick's face tightened, but he nodded in admission. "That's right. Lost all my savings, even borrowed a huge amount from Angela, but the investment went under."  

"Angela had been lending you money, huh?" Winston asked, wanting to confirm the loan from Angela. "And you haven't been able to pay her back because you lost your main job?"

“That’s correct, detective,” the man answered, his face grim with the weight of his troubles.

"Angela ever threaten to, oh, say, call the police on you?" Winston casually asked, inspecting the worn strap of his watch.

Patrick hesitated before finally sighing and admitting, "Yes, she did. More than once. I guess she had enough of my money problems and empty promises."

Somewhat satisfied, Winston took down the latest confession. Glancing around the beach, he then asked, "You were around Angela's house the evening of the explosion?" 

"Detective... it's not far from here, I often pass by when I go home," Patrick replied, his face tense at the questioning.

"Well, nobody else was around her place at that time," Winston mentioned, "Just an interesting fact."

In the awkward silence that followed, Winston then asked about the part that bothered him the most. "You use explosives much with your part-time work and your frequent training, Patrick?" 

Patrick seemed to straighten, “I have, yes, in controlled environments and with appropriate permits.” His voice was firm, perhaps a little defensive.

"Right, part of the job, I guess," Winston nodded, closing his notebook. Not another word was spoken between them as he walked away, leaving a nervous Patrick behind.

Winston gave a slow pull from his coffee as he sat across from Alvin, the typically even-tempered delivery man whose vehicle was loaded and ready for his daily route through town. Alvin's calm demeanor had earned him a reputation among the townsfolk as reliable, if not a tad peculiar due to his habit of having his lunch beside graves. 

Alvin's reliable routine encompassed the entire town including the cemetery - on today's agenda, he'd be stopping at Angela's to drop off a package. His daily routines had put him on a first-name basis with Angela, as she always made a point to personally welcome him into her home when he arrived with her deliveries. 

"So Alvin, any big plans for today?" Winston asked, making casual conversation. "Oh yes," Alvin replied, a spark in his usually placid eyes. "I've just bought a vintage Victorian-era coffin from an auction. Also, I am picking up some decommissioned explosives from a contact in the military. They're for a historical display I'm working on. Can't wait to get both set up in the living room."

This interest didn't surprise Winston. Alvin was known to frequent antique shops, specifically those that boasted a range of mortuary relics. It was odd, sure, but Alvin being odd was one of the few things that gave him character. 

"Did you know Angela?" he asked Alvin in a low tone, a hint of suspicion in his voice. Alvin nodded, "Yes. I deliver her packages regularly. Also," he said after a pause, "I was due to deliver a package to her today."

That tidbit of information Winston knew. Angela was home that day to get her package, but she had not been prepared for what the delivery contained. The investigation revealed that the fatal box delivered to Angela's house was filled with explosives, and the only man who Winston knew had any experience with such devices was Alvin.

Alvin’s past in the military gave him the exposure and knowledge about explosives that most people didn't have. It was common knowledge in their tight-knit community where personal histories were difficult to conceal. While this knowledge alone didn’t constitute evidence, it was certainly one fact of many that were swirling around in Winston’s head.

As Alvin got up to leave, Winston gave him a tight smile, "I hope you enjoy setting up your new coffin and your explosives display, Alvin," he said. “Thank you,” Alvin replied, oblivious to any undercurrent in the conversation, his calm demeanor never wavering. 

Winston finished his coffee, his mind firmly focused on the explosion that had taken Angela's life, the package that had been delivered, and questions that were begging to be answered.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the aftermath of a devastating home explosion that claims the life of Angela, seasoned Detective Winston hones in on two prime suspects: Patrick and Alvin.

Detective Winston winced a little as he pulled up to Angela's home. What was once a well kept, welcoming residence was now charred remains. All due to an explosion powerful enough to shake the neighborhood. As he began his investigation into the events leading up to the incident, one name kept surfacing: Patrick, local surfing instructor and part-time demolition worker who frequently had to handle, use, and was often training on disposing explosives at his job as a requirement of safety measures.
 
To understand this suspect more, Winston set off to meet the man at his next surfing lesson. Under the blistering sun, Patrick was there, quick to anger, bellowing at his students who seemed more frightened than focused on the waves. Several students have had grievances about his harsh teaching methods, which translated to Winston as a lack of patience.

When the session started, Winston noticed the scar that ran down the side of his face which looked ill-treated. Patrick noticed him too. His tall and sturdy figure smirked and sauntered towards Winston. "Detective, right?" his voice was rough, like sandpaper against a rough surface. "Heard about Angela, disturbing really." 

Patrick's nonchalance bothered Winston, but he gave an understanding nod. "Yeah, it is. You were doing demolition work part-time, handling and using explosives, and even have been frequently training on disposing of them, right? That could surely be a dangerous work, isn't it?" Winston queried.

"Sure is," Patrick answered, side-glancing towards his students who were still trying to catch a wave, "Just like surfing, you know, it's all about control." 

Later, Winston found out from the old records that Patrick once worked in a prison. An inmate had assaulted him, and despite being injured, he'd managed to subdue the prisoner. The incident had left him off fieldwork due to minor injuries, but his bravery had been noted. 

Winston also learned that Patrick borrowed a large sum of money from Angela. A neighbor heard Angela frequently threatening to call the cops on Patrick, but he was always around. Patrick had been seen near Angela's home that evening, the very scene of the explosion. There were no others found in the vicinity at the time.

Now, it seemed Winston was dealing with a surfing instructor who vented his frustrations on his students, an injured prison-personnel-turned-demolition-worker with frequent training on handling and disposing explosives who borrowed heavily from a woman who is now dead and was glimpsed around her house before the explosion. Interesting, certainly, but Winston knew there was more to uncover before any real pieces could begin to fall into place here. This was just the start.

Winston sat in his car, surveying through the battered fence that surrounded Angela's suburban home. The yellow tape marking off the scene of the crime fluttered eerily in the wind. Within that marked perimeter was devastation... an explosion had taken place there recently.

As Winston stepped out of his vehicle, a mail truck adorned with cheerful, vibrant colors pulled up to a house down the street. It was Alvin, a well-liked figure in the community, known best for his calm demeanor and reliability. Ex-military, he was now a delivery man and today, just like every day, he was doing his rounds. Along with the rumors of Alvin's unusual fascination with Angela and his tendency to lurk outside her home during unexpected hours, several witnesses had observed Alvin frequently retreating to his garage, where he kept a collection of various artifacts, including explosives and old photos of Angela.

Alvin had scheduled stops all over the neighborhood, but Angela - the victim in Winston's case - was one that he had on his list daily. It was on Alvin's delivery sheet that day too - a package was scheduled for Angela's house. Always punctual, Alvin would hand-deliver packages to Angela; she was always home to receive them, waiting for him at her front door with a box of his old photos of her flashed to Alvin’s mind. 

Angela's old housekeeper clued Winston in on something else. She sat, frail and teary-eyed, as she told him that Angela had recently filed a restraining order against Alvin. Despite this, he continued to visit her home with deliveries daily, revealing a persistence that bordered on stalking. 

"I learned about a lot of things in the army, Winston. How to survive on tinned beans, how to make a fire, how to assemble a rifle... Yes, I might have learnt a bit about explosives too, and have some at my place, but they're never intended for any harm," Alvin responds, visibly tense.

Winston catches sight of the mail truck and the single, small box addressed to Angela seated in the front. It was clear the last delivery of the day was made to her and it was also known that Angela was there to receive it. Angela's neighbor, Mrs. Higgins, a nosy old lady who saw everything on the block had testified to Angela personally receiving the parcel at around the same time the explosion incident occurred.

Long after Winston had left, Alvin continued to stare at the spot where Winston had been sitting, his calm exterior shattered. With dread, he remembered the package marked "explosive" in his garage, along with a stack of Angela's old photos, and the parcel he had delivered just days before Angela's house had gone up in flames.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the quiet crevices of a local library, Stephen's life came to an abrupt end, impaled by a trident; now, it's up to the tenacious Detective Winston to unravel the mystery and discern if Sophie or Lowell are responsible.

After another tiring day of working the case, Winston parked his car in a quiet, dimly lit street outside of a popular local gym. Inside was Sophie, his latest person of interest, who had gained notoriety for expressing racist viewpoints at several social gatherings. Witnesses and victims had come forth, stating that Sophie, in her fury, had confronted and threatened individuals belonging to the groups she so openly expressed prejudice against.

Sophie, who was known for her athletic prowess as a professional trident thrower, was amid an intense workout when Winston entered the facility. She was preparing for an upcoming competition, her muscles rippling under the strain of each precise throw. Her unlimited access to the gym's professional equipment made this process much easier.

Winston approached her once she finished her practice throws. "Ms. Sophie," he greeted, his gaze unwavering.

She turned, her eyes blazing with a competitive energy. "Detective Winston," she replied. "Can I help you?"

"Maybe. I'm asking around about a gym guest, Stephen. He was part of your clientele, wasn't he?" He knew the answer, having found that Stephen visited this gym regularly.

Sophie's expression hardened. "Yes," she confirmed. "So what?"

"Stephen has been murdered in the library downtown." Winston noticed Sophie's eyes flicker with surprise, or guilt perhaps. Sophie knew Stephen's routine well. His unusual, long hours spent at the library coincided with the time of the crime, a detail Sophie was well aware of. 

Sophie looked genuinely shocked. "Library?" she echoed, her brows furrowing.

"Yes, the library. Quite an unusual scene, isn't it? Especially when we found a trident near his body. It happens to be identical to the kind here in your gym," Winston added.

Immediately, Sophie blanched. She swiveled her head towards the impressive array of trident equipment, nervously mimicking a laugh. “A trident?” she repeated, “Yes… we do have tridents here for… for our clients.”

Winston changed his line of questioning. "Stephen belonged to a particular minority group, didn't he? One I've heard which you've openly threatened and discriminated against at several social events. Isn't that so?"

Sophie, visibly taken aback, struggled to reply, "I...I have...expressed my views at some social gatherings," she stammered out, her face reddening. "But what's that got to do with Stephen?"

"Well, knowing when Stephen would be at the library," Winston began, "and considering your skill with tridents, the weapon implicated in the crime – I just thought it could be worth looking into."

With those parting words, Winston left the bewildered Sophie in silence inside the gym. This first encounter provided him with more than enough to investigate Sophie further.

Winston found himself at the local train station, a place he often found solace in the comings and goings of people from all walks of life. It was here he knew he would locate Lowell, his next interviewee in regards to Stephen's untimely demise.

Lowell had been the delivery driver for the library's regular book shipments for some time now, making the morning deliveries under the cloaking silence of the pre-dawn air. As Winston deployed his questions, Lowell casually mentioned that his route included the town where the library was. Winston noted the tired dullness in Lowell's eyes as he mentioned his raise from the delivery company - it seemed like the numbing monotony of the job had not changed, nor had Lowell's general lack of enthusiasm about it.

The topic of the recent train accident came up, and what Winston found peculiar was Lowell's nonchalant response to it. Despite the usual shock and upset that strikes most people after such incidents, Lowell appeared almost unfazed, as if it were just another everyday occurrence clashing against his jaded facade.

Winston followed up on an evening invitation for a soiree at Lowell's house. This wasn't his usual cup of tea, but he knew it was an opportunity to further explore Lowell's world. The conductor's soirées were known for their unique purpose - showcasing his collection of antiquities, curiosities of historical relevance, and one particular item that never failed to impress. 

Lowell's fascination with weapons was widely known, but his pride was his trident, an instrument whose history and significance he appeared to comprehend in great depth. The antiquated weapon was a focal point of fascination among his guests, a point of conversation that led to their visible amazement.

While at the soirée, Winston overheard a brief interaction between Lowell and another attendee. The person congratulated Lowell on his raise, expressed condolences for a colleague's recent loss, and inquired about his frequent early morning deliveries to the library. Despite the layered complexities of the conversation, Lowell appeared untroubled, revealing no physical signs of sadness or empathy, and mentioned the solitary nature of his early morning deliveries. Small talk it may have seemed, these snippets of conversation provided Winston with yet another view into the intricate, strange life of Lowell.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the quiet crevices of a local library, Stephen's life came to an abrupt end, impaled by a trident; now, it's up to the tenacious Detective Winston to unravel the mystery and discern if Sophie or Lowell are responsible.

Winston slowly rubbed his temples, his heart heavy with the burden of another gruesome case that demanded his attention. The victim this time: Stephen, a courageous investigative reporter who had made one too many enemies during his pursuit of justice. Stephen had earned a name investigating and exposing illicit activities; his fearless revelations were the talk of multiple towns and cities. The crime scene was peculiar – a library, out of all places on Earth. The murder weapon? A trident.

Every homicide case left a trail, breadcrumbs that could help Winston form a faint skeleton of who the murderer might be. This time, all paths utterly and confusingly led toward Lowell, the town’s train conductor. A well-known character in his community, Lowell held soirées where he proudly displayed his many antiquities, captivating everyone with his wide collection.

That morning, after gulping down the last dregs of his lukewarm coffee, Winston geared up to pay a visit to Lowell. Lowell was a true bibliophile; this interest took him to the library often, delivering books even before the other staff arrived, quite a regular morning ritual.

"What's so captivating about these old items, Lowell?" one guest had asked at one of his soirées. With a glint in his eyes, Lowell had lifted his most prized possession, an antique trident. The reaction he garnered from his circle of acquaintances was always a mix of awe and hypnotic fascination. This was a man with a peculiar admiration for weapons, with tridents being his favourite, much to the fascination and marvel of his acquaintances.

Approaching the train station, the sound of an incoming train echoed through the high-ceilinged building. 

“You must be Lowell," Winston began, approaching the rail-thin man, who was tending to a run-down stack of worn-out books.

"Indeed I am. And you are?" Lowell responded with a tired smile, turning his attention to the dark-suited man.

“Detective Winston. I’m here to know more about your routes,” he asked, observing Lowell's weary face. Lowell’s train route famously covered numerous towns, quietly snaking through quaint little outposts and bustling cities, one of which contained the library where Stephen met his untimely demise.

Lowell's tired eyes turned sorrowful at the mention of Stephen, the brave reporter who had been closing in on his fraudulent trading of antiquities. In fact, Stephen was known for his uncanny ability to unearth and expose illegal activities, and Lowell's illegal trading was on his latest docket. This left Lowell in a precarious position and drowning in debt.

Winston held onto these observations, looking into the future with a firm resolve to expose the truth. What he had seen today was just a tip of the iceberg. But as they say, time would tell.

Winston didn't quite understand why anyone would want to throw a trident. But then again, Winston didn't understand a lot of things. He didn't understand why Stephen had been murdered in a library with a trident. And he didn't understand why Sophie, a personal trainer preparing for a trident throwing competition, seemed so vague when discussing her knowledge of Stephen.

"Stephen was at my gym a lot," Sophie remarked off-handedly as she loaded weights onto a barbell. "But we weren't exactly buddies or anything."

A few of the other gym-goers tried to engage Sophie on this topic during breaks in their workouts, to no avail. All her clients tried, but none were able to get her to discuss this topic. She expertly brushed them off, returning each time to her task. "My clients and I rarely talk about anything that's not workout related."

"Several of your clients mentioned they've tried to friend you on Facebook and follow you on Instagram, but you never respond," Winston pointed out. Her cold expression gave him the answer he expected. She's seen each request and deliberately left them pending. 

"Typical. Social media? I see all messages and requests, but I find it... cumbersome." Sophie admitted, a flicker of annoyance crossing her face as she adjusted her weight lifting gloves.

Winston glanced at the vast array of equipment laid out across the gym. "Stephen told me you were a formidable competitor. He was a big fan of trident throwers."

Sophie smirked at the comment. "Well, I am quite a pro at trident throwing."

A beat of silence passed, and Winston asked, "Did you know Stephen spent a lot of time in the library?"

For what seemed like the first time since Winston had walked in, Sophie looked away. "I knew his routine alright - gym during the day, library in the evenings. He and I, we didn't talk much... about anything outside the gym. I even knew he'd be at the library that evening of the crime."

Sophie's admission startled Winston. "You knew he'd be at the library that evening?"

Sophie only shrugged, her voice filled with indifference, "Stephen and his books. Everyone knew about his library habits. Especially that evening."

Winston suspiciously eyed the trident that was resting against the wall of the gym. A trident... just like the one found at the murder scene. "That trident over there... Is it yours?"

Sophie glanced at it and shrugged, "Yeah, it's from here. I and the others have unlimited access to the gym equipment."

In the end, Winston left the gym with more questions than answers, as Sophie went back to preparing for her competition.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the once tranquil mosque, tragedy struck as Jamal was brutally shot dead, and now it's up to Detective Winston to weave through the tangled web of secrets Mark and Gerald are entwined in.

Winston lingered at the fringes of the mosque's gates, studying the CCTV footage on his portable monitor. He was trying to absorb the details, trying to get a feel of the timeline. The footage showed Mark, a well-known local lawyer, clearly entering the mosque before the murder.

Mark was a regular attendee at the mosque for Friday prayers, and the timestamped security footage reinforced that this day was no different.

With a deep sigh, Winston packed up the monitor and made his way to the local store, where he'd arranged to meet with the store's clerks. He'd heard from the community that the quiet lawyer had been seen buying ammunition there.

The clerks confirmed it. Yes, Mark had been to the store to buy shotgun shells. It wasn’t out of place for Mark, known for his involvement with a myriad of firearm-related cases.

As Winston traveled back to his office, he reflected on the conversation he had earlier with Mark. The attorney was an influential figure in the community and often worked on cases involving firearm charges. His knowledge amassed from representing law enforcement personnel showed in his knowledgeable chatter about firearms. 

In their conversation, Mark's fear was evident. It stemmed from Jamal, the victim, who openly expressed extremist beliefs to the community, causing unease. Mark was tasked with ensuring the safety of many community members, and they’d expressed their worries about Jamal to him clearly.

Upon reaching his office, Winston began to piece together the case. He recalled at the time of the incident, Mark was present at the mosque, taking part in prayers along with the others. And Jamal… was Jamal afraid? Thought Winston. The following days would need more thorough investigation. With the data on his desk, the detective prepared himself to slowly trace his way through truth and deception in the days to come.

Winston found himself parked outside the confines of a building overflowing with culture and history - a Mosque, that now is stained with the gruesome murder of Jamal. The wind threatened to dishevel his hair as he made his way inside, crossing paths with Gerald, a violinist who frequented the same religious establishment.

"Gerald, right?" Winston called over the gusty winds, obtaining the attention of the musician.

"Yes, that's me." Gerald nodded, inspecting his violin case as though he could see through it to its contoured resident within.

"You were seen entering the Mosque at an interesting time by the security tapes, Gerald." Winston stated, keeping his gaze steady upon the man.

"Interesting time, detective?" Gerald raised a questioning brow, "I regularly come here for my prayers around this time."

Nodding, Winston eyed the violin case again, "This—a hobby for you or profession?"

"Profession. It consumes a lot of my time but I wouldn't trade it away for anything else,” Gerald responded, traces of pride crossing his features, as his fingers brushed lightly across the case. "Keeps your fingers nimble, doesn't it?" Winston asked casually.

"Absolutely," Gerald responded, smiling softly, "I suppose you could say they're suited to other delicate tasks too."

Winston's gaze darted back to Gerald's face. "Delicate tasks like...?"

"Oh, anything that requires intricate finger movements I suppose.”

This was the first time in a long time anyone had invoked curiosity in Winston, a pleasant change amidst the tragedy. Before he could indulge in this observation, a glint from a computer screen in the corner caught his eye.

“Is that public?” Winston inclined his head towards the computer.

"Why yes, Detective, it's open to all - centerpiece of this quaint little library corner," Gerald explained, before whispering in a reverential tone, "It's perfect for uninterrupted reading."

"Reading anything interesting?"

"Well, I have been immersing myself in the lives of some outstanding violinists who passed away recently. I find a kind of fascination in death, you know."

"Interesting," Winston simply responded, not daring to let a single emotion cross his face. 

Casually resting his hand on Gerald’s shoulder, Winston asked, “Gerald, do you by chance ever go to the shooting range?” 

“Funny you should ask," he answered casually, "I just bought a shotgun last week.”

“Well then," Winston said in a light tone, "maybe I’ll see you around there.”

With that, he let Gerald get back to his life. Taking one last look around the Mosque, Winston exited the building, his mind already buzzing with the next steps of his investigation.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the once tranquil mosque, tragedy struck as Jamal was brutally shot dead, and now it's up to Detective Winston to weave through the tangled web of secrets Mark and Gerald are entwined in.

Winston took a moment to clear his mind, the large white mosque in front of him only a backdrop to the chaos of scattered investigators and onlookers. The high profile murder of Jamal had the community on edge. 

A commotion caught his attention as a man named Gerald was directed towards him; a towering figure, with shaky hands that contradicted his hard-set eyes.

"Are you Winston?" Gerald's voice was soft as he extended his hand to the detective. 

"Indeed," Winston replied, examining the intricate movement of Gerald's fingers as he played with his jacket. "Play an instrument?"

"Aw, already caught me out, did you?" Gerald laughed. "I play the violin. Lot of class and vitality in a violin."

"Must have steady hands for something like that" Winston noted. The thought of handling a violin, and a shotgun, involved a high level of similar dexterity.

On Gerald's way out, Winston caught the surveillance monitor playing a video taken earlier that day. It was Gerald, entering the mosque just as the midday prayers were set to commence. This was a ritualistic routine for Gerald, arriving before the midday prayers began and always praying fervently during that time; the same time the murder happened, Detective Winston had learned during the investigation.

Winston decided to mingle with the on-goers, to see what he could gather. A local community meeting was in action, and he discovered an old friend of Gerald's named Arnold. Arnold mentioned that Gerald had openly discussed his fear of Jamal's charisma in front of the entire community during a meeting, and how he, Gerald, feels inferior to such captivating influence. Gerald's deep involvement within the mosque's day-to-day activities seemed unquestioned, even though he was openly scared of Jamal's charismatic hold on the people. 

Listening further, Winston discovered that Gerald was well-respected amongst the community, and was legally allowed to purchase firearms due to having a clean record.

Meeting Gerald again for a one-on-one, Arnold was present, making the interaction more personal. Gerald admitted to them both about his feelings of inferiority to Jamal's vast influence. 

"Gerald," Winston asked, "A week before Jamal was murdered, where were you?"

Gerald swallowed, "Well, I was out purchasing a new shotgun. Why?"

Winston simply nodded and said, "Just collecting the facts. That's all." 

He ended the conversation soon after that, wanting to get back to the office to review the evidence. As Winston watched Gerald walk away, his mind replayed their conversation. An undercurrent of fear seemed to wash over Gerald whenever Jamal's name was mentioned. But that was all facts. Nothing more.

Winston was at the crime scene, a deserted mosque, when he received news that a suspect had been identified. Mark, a local lawyer, reputed for representing law enforcement personnel was due to be interviewed. His résumé was diverse and impressive, having in several cases represented law enforcement personnel from whom he obtained extensive knowledge about firearms. As a lawyer, Mark was often called upon to play a vital role in ensuring the safety and well-being of his community while protecting the law enforcement personnel who kept it safe. Despite the sacred surroundings, a chill ran through Winston. 

Mark's office was filled with a faint scent of cologne and smoke. A number of law enforcement badges and hats met Winston's sight. "I have worked with a lot of your kind," responded Mark when asked about the artifacts. 

Winston then asked Mark if he had any known meetings today. Mark responded, "Yes, it was a standard law firm meeting with my colleagues." He paused for a moment before adding, "You know how it goes, lots of talk. And if participants thought I was repeating lines from true crime documentaries, they were right – I sometimes do it to make my point."

The conversation drifted to hobbies. Mark mentioned that he enjoyed watching true crime documentaries late into the night. He mentioned that the complex structures of these crimes and the chase to find answers gave him a thrill. "Makes me relive my cases without actually being involved. In fact, I'm constantly quoting lines from one of these during my meetings," he chuckled. "My neighbour probably knows about this too. He once told me he noticed my TV on late into the night."

One interesting fact Winston discovered was that Mark had successfully handled cases involving firearm charges. He asked Mark about this. "That's part of my job, after all," Mark replied. "Dealing with such cases is a part of ensuring the safety of this community."

The subject of firearms led Winston to ask if Mark had purchased any ammunition recently. With a raised eyebrow, Mark replied, "You're right. I did buy a couple of boxes of shotgun shells from the local store. Just wanted to know more about it from a personal perspective. The clerk even confirmed my purchase," he shrugged. 

Seeing no point in beating around the bush, Winston then asked Mark about Jamal. There was momentarily a flicker of fear that flashed across Mark's face before he turned stoic again. Mark confessed he had interacted with Jamal on a few occasions where community members expressed concerns about Jamal's extremist ideas to him. These ideas had scared him. He had confessed to a friend about his fears and it looked like a nightmare coming true.

"There's a thin line between ideas and action, detective," Mark's voice was barely above a whisper, "Unfortunately, some people don't realize it until it's too late".

As Mark was sending Winston out, he whispered, "And between you and me, it freaks my neighbor out. The only thing he says he can hear is the distinct audio from my late-night true crime documentaries."

Winston left the law firm office with a weary sigh. He knew he had a long night ahead of him, fishing for answers, following leads, exhausting every possibility until he could bring justice to Jamal.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the vibrant, pulsing heart of Times Square, Ana's life was brutally cut short by a hunting knife, leaving Detective Winston with two enigmatic suspects, Marjorie and Cecilia, and a mystery to unravel.

Winston perched at the edge of the playground, a distant figure amidst the flurry of children's laughter and the saccadic motions of swing sets. The Sands children were playing without Marjorie, their experienced nanny, conspicuously absent; the absence was unusual since Marjorie was well known for dicing up apples for the children to snack with her hunting knife. She had not taken the children for their usual afternoon jaunt to Times Square that day. Winston felt an unusual pit in his stomach.

He decided to confront Marjorie at the Sands' new triplex in Times Square. He passed by a bodega, the small television in the corner flickered - CCTV footage showcased a figure that could only be Marjorie, strolling through Times Square at the suspected time of the murder. She lived close, only a block away.

At the Sands' triplex, a crucial evidence was left untouched in the trash can. A letter, from Ana to Marjorie, lay crumpled bearing a sordid secret, Ana knew about Marjorie's fabricated immigration status. The letter bore Ana's threats too, stating clearly her intention to report Marjorie to the authorities.

As Winston was scanning about, Marjorie opened her door to him. On the kitchen counter, he noticed stacks of fruits and an empty knife holder. Winston specifically remembered seeing her just the other day at the local general store, purchasing a hunting knife identical to the one used in the murder, for her daily fruit preparation routine. Curiously, the knife was missing. Timing of things did feel odd, given her employer's recollection of Marjorie sharpening a knife that very morning. 

He questioned Marjorie, "Why would you leave the children in Times Square by themselves?". Marjorie murmured a shaky defense, "They are grown enough to look after themselves". Time and again they used to visit Times Square, an easy walking distance from the triplex, so Winston knew her excuse was not completely unfounded, but today he wasn't buying it.

As Winston left the triplex, his mind was hounded by continuous streams of 'what ifs'. All he could remember was the nervous countenance of Marjorie, in the view of a CCTV footage. She was seen leaving her employer's home at the exact time when Ana had warned about blowing her secret to the authorities. Her sudden nervousness and the hasty outing to Times Square without the nanny, all fell into an ominous sync, a sync he'd rather not confirm.

Detective Winston shuffled through his papers, casting his gaze over the case notes related to Ana's murder. He sighed, glancing out the window to the bustling city of Time Square below. 

The place of interest? One unassuming vendor stand amongst the neon chaos that seemingly never switched off, a spectacle unto itself. This is where Cecilia spent all her days, standing by her table piled with knick-knacks, everything from flashy sunglasses to novelty t-shirts. On the floor beneath her overflowing table were stacks of books, each one a testament to her visits to the neighboring bookstore; Cecilia kept every book she bought, never lending or losing a single one.

"Looks like this time, even Time Square couldn't quite keep its darkest secrets hidden," Winston muttered to himself, contemplating the murder that had unfolded in Time Square during the bustling evening hours.

There was an alley near the bookstore, and Winston settled himself in the shadows, lighting up a smoke, waiting. As dusk ebbed into the square, Winston spotted Cecilia helping herself with a fresh book from the crime section of the bookstore. Winston found it intriguing; her peculiar fascination with crime seemed unsettling amongst her chats with her fellow street sellers. 

By the time Winston approached her stand, the crowds had thinned, and she had already packed up for the day. She was an impressive storyteller, weaving cautionary tales of infamous killers she had read about from her newly acquired books. As the story progressed, he spotted the glint of apprehension from a few fellow vendors. 

"Ana sure had an inquisitive spirit, didn't she?" Winston inquired casually, watching Cecilia carefully. 

Faces lost in an ocean of bustling bodies, Cecilia recalled noticing Ana with a pointed curiosity towards her stand. With her camera, Ana had been a constant presence, focused on the trinkets sold and the vendor before her.

Ana had been snooping around, asking about legal vendor requirements. Cecilia, confused initially, shrugged it off as Ana's nosy nature. A tale of odd events unfurled as Cecilia recollected finding a message on Ana's forgotten phone, an anonymous tip to the police. 

A rush of tailored suits and impatient tourists occurred, even at these late hours on the square, as the mystery unraveled. Winston returned himself to the chaos of Time Square, leaving Cecilia to her own evening ritual. The curious, seemingly benign vendor with her penchant for crime lore and engaging storytelling was but one corner piece in the grand puzzle of Ana's untimely death.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the vibrant, pulsing heart of Times Square, Ana's life was brutally cut short by a hunting knife, leaving Detective Winston with two enigmatic suspects, Marjorie and Cecilia, and a mystery to unravel.

In the heart of the city, Time Square flashed and hummed with its characteristic madness. Winston stood by a knife vendor, studying the surroundings and the tiny details on the numerous steel blades that the stall offered, a permanent fixture amidst the bustling metropolis. The merchandise varied from small purpose knives to larger hunting blades - the very kind the murderer had used on Ana under a dimly lit Times Square in the cool of the evening.

"Crowded, ain't it?" The voice from behind the stand cut through the noise. Cecilia, the vendor, looking comfortably settled amidst her deadly contraband.

"Yes, it's surprising that a murder could have even been committed here amidst all these people, especially during the bustle of the evening hours." Winston replied nonchalantly.

"Ah, yes, poor Ana," Cecilia responded, keeping her eyes busy on the sturdy hunting knife she uses daily at her stand, continuing to work. "She gave me an odd feeling, always around here... snapping pictures of my stand, asking about legal implications for vendors and all."

"Oh?" Winston raised an eyebrow. "Did you two interact much?"

"Can't say we did... She did ask questions about the legality of such sales and other specific vendor-related requirements. Seemed keen on the legality of such sales, she was. 'course, everything's above board here," Cecilia stated, raising a knife to the evening sky, inspecting it for any unseen flaws before putting it down with her other blades for sale.

With the swiftness of someone who had used knives for years, Cecilia felt at ease with these tools of destruction. The hunting knife she held now was her personal favorite; it was what she used daily. She had even taken classes to master it. 

"I'm set up here all day, every day," Cecilia explained, seeing Winston's gaze darting over her stand. "Evening tends to attract more customers, people coming off work, I suppose."

"Ana seemed a bit too interested in my stall," Cecilia added after a pause and glanced at Winston. "Found an anonymous tip against me on her phone. Not very sporting, I'd say."

Just another day in the city, Winston thought as he finished up his tour of the vendor’s stand, a tiny permanent colony amidst the swirling chaos of Time Square.

Detective Winston pulled out his notebook, sitting alone in his sedan. He scanned his notes about the deceased woman, Ana, a case of rampant aggression in the heart of Times Square that simply astounded him.

A notable red flag kept popping up amongst his notes: Marjorie, an experienced live-in nanny for the Johnson family, who were known to frequent Times Square — owing primarily to Marjorie's routine of taking the children to the bustling location. Her odd choice of a hunting knife for a fruit cutter - something she'd often use to cut fruit for the Johnson kids, was unique, but not particularly unsettling until matched with its recent absence from the Johnson household. Additionally, there was a piece of evidence that traced Marjorie to a local store which sold the same type of hunting knife, on the day of the murder, thus adding to Winston's growing interest in her. 

Winston found himself curious about all this, a smokescreen that might be hiding something. Thumbing a few pages back, Winston retraced the parents' description of Marjorie as obsessively clean, always tidying in the Johnson home. According to the parents, the house was always spotless and the nanny never seemed to part with her usual duster. 

As he reached the last few lines, he recollected an interesting observation – an eyewitness placed Marjorie in the vicinity of Times Square at the approximate hour Ana had been murdered. With his quick note-taking, he jotted down another unexpected detail shared by a separate witness – the Johnson boys had been seen at that same hour in Times Square without their usual, vigilant nanny. Noting down a quick reminder to follow up with the parents, Winston lowered his notebook. The Huntsman knife, a tool she'd deftly used for slicing fruit for the children and now missing from its usual spot in the kitchen of the Johnson home, placed Marjorie high on his list of persons of interest. 

Additional evidence he mused over was a recollection from Marjorie's employer, who mentioned seeing her sharpen the knife's edge the very morning of the murder. This image was not incriminating on its own, but when coupled with the fact Marjorie always seemed armed with cleaning supplies, questions arose. How far would someone go to hide dirty secrets under the guise of cleanliness?

Winston sighed, running a hand over his worn notebook. Parents praised Marjorie for the impeccable cleanliness of the living room, which, Winston recalled, was spotless to the point of suspicion. Even when the room looked clean, Marjorie would spend seemingly excessive time maintaining the pristine condition.

Finally closing the worn leather notebook, Winston glanced at his wristwatch, updating himself with the fact that Marjorie was recorded leaving the Johnson estate around the very time that Ana had met her grim fate. These facts weighed heavily on him – each piece a fragment in a deeply intricate puzzle.

“Quite the nanny we have here,” Winston murmured to himself, starting the engine to make his way to the Johnson estate. Details done, actions justified; yet an unresolved cloud of doubt hung in the air. Only time would unravel the truth.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the wake of a gruesome flamethrower murder at a local soccer field, seasoned detective Winston steps up to investigate, with suspects Sophia and Larry under his watchful eye.


"Detective Winston," Sophia greeted as she shuffled her cardboard coffee cup in her hands nervously. They were standing on the edge of the football field where the murder had taken place.

"Sophia," Winston nodded, looking out at the half-time huddle of sweaty, tired players - the same scene where Savannah had taken her last breath. 

Sophia was a journalist. She'd been covering the match when Savannah was killed, following her usual line of reportage. Today, she'd been on the field, right where it all happened. Savannah's murder had occurred right at halftime and yet, nobody seemed to know anything. 

"So, it's been a while since your reports on the military exhibition, correct?" Winston asked, keeping his face calm but watchful to catch any change in her expression.

"Yeah,  it was a couple of months ago. I still have the flamethrower I'd managed to keep, for research and, you know... reminders," Sophia said, her gaze flickering toward the field. 

Winston nodded. He knew that keeping memorabilia wasn't uncommon in her trade. Did it provide Sophia with a flamethrower when she needed one?

"Savannah, were you two friends?" Winston asked, keeping an eye on the middle of the field where everything had happened.

"We knew each other... She threatened to reveal my source, ruin my credibility," Sophia sighed, staring at her untouched coffee. 

Sophia's job was at stake, Winston knew; in a field like journalism, credibility mattered.

"Why didn't you tell anyone about the threat?" 

Sophia shifted uncomfortably, "I had heavily invested time and energy in this article. I was protecting my...trust in the field. My source was my lifeline." 

Winston didn't reply but noted her skittishness in revealing her source even now.

"Look, the match is starting!" Sophia pointed out to the field as the whistle blew.

Winston just nodded, eyeing the field where the murder had taken place. If he was to solve this case, he had to sift through the evidence slowly and carefully. Even when it came from a journalist faced with the threat of losing her job and credibility. Even when it was wrapped up in the middle of a football game.

Winston crunched on a stale coffee flavoured donut while wiping away the grim remnants from the computer monitor in his rundown office. He had been staring at the sport section of the local newspaper that spoke about the location of the unfortunate demise of Savannah, a keen enthusiast and promoter of sports in the city, especially soccer who also happened to be a strong opponent of Larry in politics. 

The photograph of the soccer field was chilling, almost like a badly done modern graffiti that had charcoalled the grass in obscene patterns. A flamethrower had been the murder weapon and such a trait of weaponry could point to only a certain group of people who had the experience to operate such a complicated tool of destruction, typically war veterans, like Larry.

Larry lived in a secluded house surrounded by woods, and held his position as head of a local survivalist group. Very often, his colleagues complained of Larry turning off his phone and avoiding them after work. This lack of response to text messages, calls, or any other means of digital communication could only be explained by Larry's choice to retreat in solidarity and bare minimal social contact. 

Winston sighed, pushed away the paper, and prepared to visit Larry. As usual, in unsociable fashion, Larry declined Winston's invitation to join his colleagues. 

Winston knocked on the rustic door of Larry's eerie looking cabin. When Larry opened the door, he looked like he had just finished a drill. He was sweating, hair a disheveled mess, his posture was rigid and alert. His eyes darted to his wristwatch, hinting towards a habit that he exhibited during various events, checking time frequently. "Larry," Winston said.

Larry recognised him and invited him in albeit reluctantly. A quick glance around the room was enough to see survivalist instincts visible in every corner. In amongst the survival gear was a flamethrower, a common item found in survivalists tool kits. But Winston ignored it and tried to talk politics. 

Larry seemed keen to steer the conversation towards Savannah - his fiery political rival. Winston learned Larry had a habit of attending all the political rallies personally. Savannah's recent rally was public, held downtown at the center square, and as always, Larry had been present. 

Trying to make Larry more comfortable, Winston asked Larry about his social life and why he declined invitations to join others. Larry just shrugged, avoided Winston's gaze, and said he wasn't interested in what others were doing.

His answers lacked conviction, but Winston held his professionalism and didn't push any further. He thanked Larry for his time and left.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the wake of a gruesome flamethrower murder at a local soccer field, seasoned detective Winston steps up to investigate, with suspects Sophia and Larry under his watchful eye.


Winston was staring at Savannah's campaign poster — the one with her promising smile and eyes full of assurance. Savannah, who was leading in the polls, was clearly the people's choice for the election. The upcoming political rally had been plastered about town for weeks, making it an inevitability known to all.

Winston scratched at an internal itch and trudged onto another stakeout. Larry, the man he was looking to question, was apparently active in a local survivalist group. Flipping open his notebook, Winston noted that Larry was a war veteran who had gone to significant lengths campaigning himself. Posters of Larry bearing the tagline "Whatever it takes" dotted the town too.

Winston watched as Larry scrutinized each one with such intensity that it seemed like his entire identity was tied to the outcome of this election. The survivalist meetings took place in Larry's private property, which he had converted into a fortified camp after pumping his entire fortune into his campaign.

Winston decided to pay a visit to Larry to know more about him and his involvement in the race. They met at Larry's camp, a spit-and-polish place that reflected Larry's military background. Crisp flags snapped in the wind and the entire setting was punctuated by the distinct scent of gun oil.

"Thank you for your service," Winston began, extending a handshake to Larry who returned it with an iron grip. It's well-known that war veterans like Larry are experienced with various forms of weaponry, including flamethrowers. True to this, an errant flamethrower was left out in the open at his camp, catching Winston's eye. A flame thrower, not entirely strange for a survivalist's camp, was an interesting detail, considering the bizarre circumstances of Savannah's death.

As they chatted, Winston learned that Larry and Savannah were political rivals. Larry preferred to attend every rally personally. In fact, even though they stood on opposing political platforms, Larry never missed any of Savannah's rallies.

"I respect my opponent," said Larry, his gaze distant. "It's her policies I have a problem with."

Winston wrapped up the brief visit with a polite nod. As he left Larry's camp, the veteran-turned-politician watched with a grim smile that left Winston looking back at Savannah's campaign poster with a different perspective.

Under the harsh whiteness of the police station lights, Winston eyed the smartly dressed woman with a critical gaze. Sophia, they called her. A journalist. She was a fine-boned woman, older, maybe late forties, with a reputation for relentless pursuit of stories. And not just that, she had a remarkable reputation of not lying or hiding truths, even under the most severe pressures.

"Sophia, you worked on coverage of the military exhibition last month, right?" he started, watching her eyes carefully for subtle reactions.

"Yes, I did," she said coolly. She looked him directly in the eyes, without a hint of evasion. "I am entrusted with sometimes sensitive information. I don't lie or hide truths, detective. I take my job quite seriously."

Seeing her intensity, Winston was not surprised. She was invested in her career, in truth-seeking, more than most. But her career, it seemed to Winston, was teetering on the edge. His notes said something about job stability issues.

"I heard from various sources that your job as a journalist could be at risk, Sophia."

A flicker of annoyance crossed Sophia's eyes. "Every job carries elements of risk and taking risks is crucial for growth, detective," she replied firmly.

Winston took note of that and moved on to another point. "Is it true that you managed to keep a flamethrower from the exhibition?"

A pause. Then a nod. "I did keep a flamethrower... to study it further for my report. Is that a crime?" she asked pointedly, her reputation for truthfulness evident. A defiant posture, not backing down easily, but then that's what made her good at her job, the detective reasoned.

"Well... does the name Savannah ring a bell?" Winston asked, trying not to flinch at the sudden stiffness that came over Sophia's features. "She knew you had a secret source, didn't she, Sophia?"

Again, a pause, then a pointed glance before she finally said, "Yes, she did... and she threatened to jeopardize the whole thing by revealing it publicly." The bitterness in her voice betrayed the gravity of that threat.

Just as he was about to dive into that area further, he was reminded of a peculiar bit of information he'd acquired. "Sophia, you were asked about some... scars? At a dinner party?"

Suddenly, all of Sophia's poise seemed to wither away. "If you’re referring to the dinner at the mayor's house, yes, I was asked about them," she answered evasively. Then she stood up in alarm, eyes flashing with a mix of fear, defiance and something Winston couldn't quite place.

"I think this conversation is over, detective. Thank you for your time," were her words before she exited the room hastily.

Winston sighed, shoving his hands in his pockets. The chapter with Sophia wasn't over yet. Not by a long shot. He admired her relentless pursuit of the truth, of not dodging or lying.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the midst of bustling shoppers, Troy meets his untimely demise by a bear trap, thrusting Detective Winston into a perplexing mall investigation with Alex and Clyde as prime subjects.

Detective Winston eyed the peculiar object on his desk, set down his steaming cup of joe, and furrowed his brows. It was a bear trap, photoed very professionally, apparently a purchase option from a hunting gear store. The same kind of bear trap that Alex, the store's owner, had previously confirmed was in his inventory. The kind that was used to kill Troy, the political figure who was stirring up legislation that might directly harm Alex's business. The same Troy with whom Alex had several disagreements over their contradicting business policies.

Officer Gordon stuck his head through the door frame of Winston's office and said, "That's our guy, Alex. Well, not ours just yet, not officially. He owns that hunting store and certainly stocks up on various gears including bear traps. Bear traps that have a little too much in common with the one that killed Troy. Furthermore, Alex not only seeks profit from the sales but also frequently talks about wanting to get payments from the store."

"I see," Winston responded, his voice as gruff as ever. Hunting gears and jockeys, a rather unusual combination.

"Alex was seen there, right on the mall security cameras," Gordon continued, flipping through his notebook, "At the mall, I mean, on the tragic day that Troy was murdered in the same mall. He's there every day, apparently. Always, seeking to extract whatever profits he can, for he's constantly paying out more than he's earning."

Winston considered Alex's unpaid bills, the taxes that he feared due to Troy's legislation. "Intense on protecting his business, this Alex, huh?"

"Like a bantam rooster,"  Gordon replied, allowing a brief smirk. "Aggressive, seemingly always under fire from Troy's politics—affecting his particular industry. The guy is desperate, seeking any revenue he can squeeze from his daily store visits." 

"Where is he now, Gordon?" 

"In his store, most likely, clinging onto any profits he can manage. It's just about the only stability he has given his current financial standing."

Winston hoisted himself up, grasped the photograph of the bear trap in one hand, his coffee in the other, and left the office, off to talk to this Alex character who, if appearances suggested so much, was living life on the edge of bankruptcy because of Troy. But, only time would tell if this Alex has more to his story than just an affinity for hunting gears, desperate need for store payments, and a few significant debts.

Standing in the cavernous, bustling landscapes of the city shopping mall, Winston took in the lurid pastel shades, the shoppers with their arms filled with bags, and the little kids scampering about. Confirmation from security footage had ensured him that Troy had been seen here on the day of the murder, the same way he'd bring himself anywhere else he went - frequently and with money in mind.

As Winston walked, he passed the small kiosk heralding ads from local businesses. A particular one popped out - Clyde's Auto Shop, conveniently situated just a stone's throw away from the mall. A frown creased Winston's brow. The same Clyde that was in his little black notebook, the same Clyde who had close business interactions with Troy. But that was a matter for a different time.

Inside his little black notebook, Winston had noted that Clyde had previously loaned Troy, a regular customer, money for repairs on his car. Winston also knew that Troy was unable to pay Clyde back at the moment, forcing Clyde to struggle financially. These were all connections worth considering.

At the crime scene, a half-removed bear trap looked horrendously out of place amidst the clean tiled floors and tastefully constructed backgrounds that made up the mall's scenery. Whoever had the audacity to bring that thing here...

After calling it a day with the crime scene, he headed over to confront Clyde. The shop was a wrenching sight. Machines of various shapes and sizes lay strewn about, all producing a clanking noise that threatened to give Winston a headache. Clyde was evidently absent from his place behind the counter, but his workers pointed him out in the mall, where they claimed he was buying new equipment for his struggling auto shop.

Finding Clyde in a store struck Winston as unusual. "Clyde," Winston called out, making the man jump.

"Well, Howdy there," Clyde grunted back, evidently not in the best of moods.

"Heard about Troy?" Winston asked, watching Clyde's reaction closely.

"Bloke still owes me money for his car repairs," Clyde confessed, "Struggling as it was, I even gave him loans. He was unable to pay me back."

Winston definitely noticed the familiarity Clyde spoke of Troy with. There was something brewing, he could sense it.

“Work, yeah,” Clyde huffed, “Sure seems there’s always something urgent at the prison.”

Ah, the prison. Winston distinctly remembered Clyde's rather infamous stint at the local prison, where he worked as a corrections officer. Apparently, Clyde was infamously frequently absent during his tenure. And that one particular absence... It coincided with a notorious inmate's escape, who was serving his sentence for a brutal crime. Clyde had claimed he was on duties, doing his rounds, and just did not notice the escape. This was something difficult to swallow, suspicious even.

Clyde had left that job later, after facing several complaints about his behaviour. Winston made a note of everything, knowing that they may lead to something substantial later on.

As he left the shopping mall, Winston found his sight drawn to the auto shop again. It was billowing out a cloud of dark smoke. He squinted, but his gaze was yanked back to the mall, to the pastel hues, and unbearable anticipation. The murderer was still out here somewhere, Winston vowed to find him. After all, they were all characters in this play, but he was the conductor. And it was time he directed them towards the end.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the midst of bustling shoppers, Troy meets his untimely demise by a bear trap, thrusting Detective Winston into a perplexing mall investigation with Alex and Clyde as prime subjects.

Winston stared at the case file on his desk, a half-drunk cup of cold coffee to his side. The victim, Troy, had been found dead in a shopping mall in one of the most unusual circumstances he'd seen: in a bear trap. It was a gruesome scene and one that didn't make much sense.

Confused, Winston made his way to Clyde's auto repair shop. A greasy, dust-covered sign welcoming customers and a few older model cars dotted the yard. The mound of mechanical traps of all kinds added an eerie touch to the scene.

"Clyde," he asked, when a haggard man emerged wiping motor oil off of his hands.

"That's me." came the terse reply.

Winston introduced himself and saw Clyde pause for a moment before shaking his hand. He told him that he wanted to know more about Troy, who according to the information he gathered, was a regular customer at Clyde's.

After a sigh, he nodded, his gaze darkening. "Yeah, Troy was a good customer. Always had car troubles. But he was into me pretty deep... owed me some dough for the work I had done."

Winston then shared a piece of information that Clyde didn't seem privy to - Troy had been at the mall earlier in the day, just before his untimely death.

It was at this point Winston noticed a bear trap amongst the litter of mechanical devices. "You work on those too?" He gestured towards the trap, appearing casual.

Clyde glanced at the trap and nodded. "Sometimes. For pest control and such. People bring them in, they're not workin' right, I fix 'em."

Clyde then went on about how he was on the brink of closing the shop due to his financial struggles. He needed to constantly upgrade his equipment but lacked the necessary funds to do so.

In fact, he too had been at the mall on the same day as Troy. "I was there to buy new equipment for the shop," Clyde added.

It was interesting, Winston thought, given that Clyde's shop was practically a stone's throw away from the location of the murder. He made a mental note to follow-up on that.

As Winston thanked Clyde and turned to leave, he noticed a large sign hanging on the wall with the bold letters stating, "We fix all traps – yes, even bear traps."

Well, he thought to himself, that's a lot of loose ends to tie up. As he walked away, he felt the faint stirrings of a puzzle starting to form. He only hoped he could solve it in time.

Winston, a seasoned police investigator, looked at the shop-till-you-drop nightmare known as a shopping mall - specifically the spot where Troy, a local political leader who proposed specific taxes impacting the horse racing industry, met his untimely demise. The weapon of choice still spun his mind, a bear trap... not something you find in an urban environment. 

He had a long list of suspects, and mall security footage placed next on his interview list, a man named Alex, right there. Alex - a local jockey who runs a business seriously affected by recent economic stress and challenged by the policies and taxes Troy proposed. Alex had been struggling financially for several months, paying out more in expenses than he was earning. Winston had seen intriguing footage of Alex grooming Troy's hair at the gathering that night - an odd sight indeed. 

Winston caught the weary Alex, with visible signs of stress, as he was wrapping up his day at the local race track. A taxing industry was even further burdened by the policies Troy supported. They exchanged nods.

"How are you related to Troy?" Winston asked, to initiate their conversation.

"I wasn't really close to him, but we knew each other from the horse race circles. Disagreements happen, everyone has their views," Alex answered ambiguously. 

Looking to probe further into one of his primary leads, Winston continued, "What was your disagreement about exactly?"

"Taxes... policies. Troy proposed this new set of taxes that hit right into my industry," Alex replied, visibly irked, "You’re aware of the dwindling finances of the horse racing, aren't you? I have been paying out more than I have been earning for several months now."

Next, Winston needed to verify some unusual behavior noted by others, "I’ve heard that you have an unusual hobby. Is it true?”

Alex seemed relieved at the change of subject, "Oh yes, quite an unusual hobby; I collect bear traps." 

"Quite an unusual hobby indeed," Winston echoed, playing it cool. 

"After a tedious day at work, I stopped by the mall to shop for some, on the day of the incident," Alex casually mentioned. 

"I see," Winston said, trying not to betray any emotion, already piecing together the facts from the mall security footage, the increased taxes, and the weird yet timely hobby. He made a note and prepared for his next interview.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the wake of Lola's mysterious katana-driven demise at a secluded mountain cabin, Detective Winston finds himself entangled in a web of suspicion, with Isabelle and Frank peering anxiously from its corners.

In the tempered light of the police station, Detective Winston flipped open the file for his latest case. Pinned to the top was a grim photo of Lola, the victim, marking another life prematurely ended. A set of intimate text messages from Lola to another man caught his attention, reportedly found by Isabelle. Winston found the content of the messages interesting, adding more intrigue to the case. Lower in the pile, there was a picture of Isabelle, his prime suspect. 

With a dedication observed during her thrice weekly visits, Isabelle had become a familiar figure in her local dojo, her commitment noted by fellow practitioners. Winston dialed the dojo and had a brief but informative conversation with her sensei, before putting the phone back with a small sigh. Her sensei revealed that Isabelle had been seen sharpening her Katanas after each session.

David, Lola's life coach, had confided a lot in Isabelle, spending a considerable amount of time alone with her, a fact that Winston found odd. Isabelle had not only found some of Lola's intimate messages, but she had also seen Lola kissing the unknown man, making her knowledge even more suspect. The phone buzzed back into life, David at the other end of the line filling Winston in on his last intimate conversation with Isabelle. Their relationship was unconventional - it didn’t seem standard for a life coach to be so close to a friend of their clients.

“What brings you up here, Detective?” Isabelle asked when Winston arrived at her door. She was out of breath and had chalk dusted on her pants, evident either from her routine rock climbing training or her regular hike which she often indulged in.

Winston followed Isabelle into the house and entered a room solely dedicated to her Katana collection. Some were ornate, clearly for show, but others showed signs of recent care, with the wear marks from constant sharpening along the blade, the same the sensei had mentioned.

“So, you visit Lola’s mountain cabin often?” Winston asked, shifting the conversation. 

“Yeah, I’ve been up there a handful of times when Lola is alone. It’s quiet and at a considerable altitude, inaccessible without physical fitness, perfect to clear the mind,” Isabelle admitted. She described the layout of the cabin in detail, showing her familiarity with the place. But her voice seemed somewhat strained, the memory of seeing Lola and the man in an intimate exchange casting a shadow.

They talked a while longer about the trails to the cabin, which Winston rightly noted required considerable physical strength. The conversation then swung to David, and they spoke freely about their close, somewhat unconventional friendship.

Upon his return to the dojo, Winston observed the elegance and precision with which the sensei moved a katana. His mind drifted back to the crime scene, Lola’s body lying in an eerily tranquil way, as if her death had been executed by someone trained in a lethal art. 

Back in the car, Winston flicked his cigarette butt into the darkness, a chill passing over him as he thought of Lola, alone in the cabin at the time she was killed. What a dark sense of humor life had, he reflected, as he prepared to tackle the case.

As Winston paced the floor of his small and cluttered office, he reviewed his notes about Lola's murder. The whole scene of the gruesome act was set in a secluded mountain cabin, salted wounds for the peaceful surroundings. She had invited Frank for a work retreat, a secret invitation that he told no one about, and Winston decided that perhaps it was time to visit the suspect.

As a biologist, Frank was surrounded by microscopes and lab coats by the day, while his nights were spent in a dojo, practicing martial arts. Winston's curiosity piqued upon learning of his weapon of choice, the katana. 

Winston carefully examined Frank's martial arts record and noticed Frank's regularity in practicing with his katanas. A clue that Winston found interesting was the fact that Frank recently acquired a sharpening stone. An unusual purchase when you considered his profession.

Frank's laboratory colleagues had divulged that he often had a peculiar habit. He would abruptly leave work and colleagues found new insect bites on his skin afterwards. This could be nothing more than a biologist exploring his environment, but Winston had a gut feeling that there was more to it.

Winston had also come across Frank's bank statements, where funds were frequently withdrawn to flight booking sites. Odd for someone whose work seemed to revolve mostly around his lab, but not out of the ordinary either.

Frank's home had companion pets who were frequently ill during his unexplained absences. Curiously, this seemed to coincide with his unusual hobby of abruptly leaving his office and heading in the unknown, Winston made a mental note to investigate Frank's suspicious departures more closely.

On the day of Lola's murder, Frank's schedule had no entries. Couple that with an eye-witness account of him being seen near the mountain cabin and Winston decided it was time to reach out to this elusive biologist. As he dialed Frank's number, Winston knew that he was getting closer to unveiling the truth. "Mr. Frank," he said, "It's Detective Winston, let's talk."
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In the wake of Lola's mysterious katana-driven demise at a secluded mountain cabin, Detective Winston finds himself entangled in a web of suspicion, with Isabelle and Frank peering anxiously from its corners.

Winston gazed contemplatively at a mountain cabin photo where Lola had met her end. He grimaced as his gaze landed on the katana. This was not a run-of-the-mill crime; it was seemingly conducted with a professional touch.

Bringing himself back from the troubling images, he turned his attention to Isabelle. As Lola's life coach, she could potentially shed some light on the complexities surrounding her death. 

Flicking novel-like through an accumulation of notes, he discovered that Isabelle was not as open as most coaches. She engaged with her clients predominantly through privacy-focused platforms and kept any personal details off public forums. The agreement she held with her clients also contained a clause about prioritizing privacy and confiding in her seemed to be one of her requirements, and David --the other man Lola had an affair with-- was no exception. He confided in her, quite frequently as it turned out.

However, what caught his attention was a note hinting at her discovery of intimate text messages between Lola and another man. That's why she confided uneasily with David more, ushering them into lengthy personal conversations and extraneous time spent alone. They had far more interactions outside the coaching sessions than was typical.

Pulling into Isabelle's driveway, Winston noticed the peace that surrounded her home. Inside, Isabelle waited patiently on an austere chair, a sharp contrast to the decor of the rest of the home.

"Busy day?" A plain, professional question to start off with. 

"Indeed. Three sessions at the Dojo and then some client interactions," Isabelle replied. 

"Wow, that's a tight routine. At the Dojo, I assume you work with the Katana?" Winston tried to keep his tone casual.

"That's correct. I try to keep them in the best condition... sharpening included."

Her house was decidedly sparse, but one room was markedly different. A room dedicated to her treasured collection of Katana. Delicate, sharp, deadly works of art.

Isabelle was not one to engage unnecessarily; she had expressed as much. But there was one occasion where she did seem to talk, quite a bit actually. To David.

"Have you met David outside of the coaching sessions?" Winston asked, as he examined one of the Katanas. 

"Yes, a few times. Our schedules happen to coincide," she responded, her eyes averted.

"And some of these encounters were in regards to the intimate messages Lola was sharing with the other man?"

"Yes, that's correct."

"In connection with Lola, perhaps?"

Isabelle's gaze hardened. "Lola was stepping over boundaries - I saw her kissing David."

The session ended with more questions than answers for Winston. He casually bid her goodbye, having established she preferred minimal social interactions.

"Gotta head back, Isabelle, can't keep the precinct waiting. You have a good day now." He put on his hat and walked out, leaving Isabelle with her thoughts.

Detective Winston sat hunched over his quaint oak desk, his dark eyes scanning over the phone records of the deceased, Lola. He jotted down a quick note - Lola had dialed one number numerous times, the number belonging to a certain Frank. It seemed Lola made a habit of contacting him.

His notes also mentioned that multiple witnesses had recently spotted Frank practicing with his Katanas at a local martial arts studio. His swordsmanship had certainly improved, it showed dedication.

The following day, Winston found himself driving up the mountain to meet with Frank, a well-respected biologist having an impressive and crucially vital academic career. Frank's workspace was littered with numerous awards and commendations highlighting the value of his work; it was clear that his reputation was important to him.

"Good afternoon, Frank," Detective Winston greeted, extending a hand.

Frank looked up from his microscope and shook the detective's hand, "Afternoon, detective. What brings you here?"

"Lola invited you to her cabin under the semblance of a work retreat, isn't it?" Winston asked, leaning against the lab desk.

"Yes," Frank replied reluctantly, "But I never told anyone else about that."

Winston nodded and changed the topic, grabbing one of the photos off the table. It was shot a few days ago, Lola and Frank seemed to be in a heated discussion, "Care to share what this altercation was about?"

"Nothing serious, just some professional disagreements," Frank dismissed hurriedly, seeming eager to move past the topic.

As Winston glanced around the room, he noticed something else; A pair of katanas meticulously maintained and displayed on the wall. "You have an interest in martial arts, Frank?"

Frank seemed to relax a little, leaning back from the microscope, "Yes, I've been taking classes recently. It helps me focus."

"And what about these?" Winston asked, indicating towards the Katanas.

"Ah those..." Frank trailed off. "Well yes, I've been practicing with them, they're my favorite weapon of choice in martial arts," he admitted, quickly adding, "but they're only for practice."

Winston headed to the local hardware store after the meeting to confirm another fact. Frank had indeed bought a sharpening stone just a couple of days ago.

At the end of the day, he checked out Frank's public schedule - it was free on the day Lola got murdered, just as his hunch had indicated. He cross-checked with some bystanders, who also confirmed seeing Frank near the mountain cabin on the same day.

As Winston wrapped up his day of investigation, he couldn't help but remember the one last crucial piece of information. Lola had been blackmailing Frank with evidence of academic misconduct, tarnishing the career he was so proud of.
question: Who is the most likely murderer?

narrative:
In a grimly lit motel room, Detective Winston finds himself face to face with Adam's charred remains and two potential suspects: Gregory and Alfred. The murder weapon? An unlikely and gruesome choice, a flamethrower.


Detective Winston noticed Alfred almost immediately at the motel tournament. Not only because Alfred was a stellar athlete known for his flamethrower skills, but also due to his nonchalant display of his large, mysterious tool bag. This was particularly noticeable each time Winston spotted him leaving the motel on full moon nights, ready for a game. 

Winston approached Alfred after he ended yet another victorious game under the full moon. "Alfred, right?" Winston diplomatically asked. 

"Yep, that's me." Alfred replied, a hint of pride mirroring in his words. The detectable pride wasn't out of place considering Alfred always seemed to score the winning point on the nights the moon was full.

"And you always play on full moon nights, right?" Winston inquired, relying on his prior knowledge of the tournament's nature.

Alfred answered, chuckling a bit to himself, "A little superstitious, I guess. I do always seem to score the winning point when the moon's full."

As he spoke, Winston became aware of an oversized tool bag resting near Alfred's feet. He couldn't ignore the temptation of questioning, "That's a pretty big bag you got there Alfred, what do you use that for?"

Alfred paused, "Well.., it's for my flamethrower. They don't just hand those out to anyone, you know. I'm a pro at handling them."
